Organised crime groups are documented as having high levels of involvement with regulated industries, including the sex industry and the adult entertainment venues. Corruption in the agriculture sector often involves bribery and manipulation of government contracts. The complexity of government contracts and financing flows between companies, government officials, and citizens creates opportunities for corrupt practices. For instance, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Office of Investigations conducts investigations into various forms of corruption, including bribery and false statements
Thus, a clever and unethical seller can successfully bribe inspectors to pass off cheaper conventionally grown grain for the more expensive organic kind and make a huge profit.
Besides this, agricultural supply chain was complex and consisted of many stakeholders, such as farmers, distributors and retailers. In the chain of agricultural industrialization, agricultural related companies play a direct role in many countries. Nevertheless, many agricultural listed companies tend to make some false financial statements to conceal or falsely report their financial status  in order to protect their own interests.
An agricultural company may face an incentive to bribe customs officials because of the risk of product spoliation. Corruption in agricultural production poses problems for large and small landholders around the globe. Corruption issues affect land title and tenure, credit availability, quality of supplies, water allocation, marketing, and the development of agribusinesses. These problems are common to both developing and transition economies. In transition economies, however, the governments are more involved in supplies, production and marketing and so there are relatively more opportunities for corruption. Yet societies depending on survival agriculture are affected proportionally more by corruption as the bribes farmers pay impact a higher percentage of their already low income.

title: Amusement & Recreation - Environmental
body:
Although theme parks are great sources of entertainment, they are also a cause of concern for environmentalists. These extensive operations require huge swaths of land, as well as large supplies of energy and water. Theme parks have a variety of direct and indirect effects on the environment. They contribute to air pollution indirectly through the massive amounts of energy needed to keep the park running. Fossil fuels are burned to power rides and facilities, heat or cool buildings, and light the streetlamps that line the sidewalks and pathways of the park.
Moreover, an attraction that draws in large crowds of people for extended periods, especially one with many concession stands, is bound to create and collect a lot of trash. Some of the trash can be recycled, but those materials still need to be sorted and taken to a recycling facility, increasing fossil fuel consumption. Trash that cannot be recycled typically ends up in a landfill, where it contributes to global warming by emitting methane, a greenhouse gas, as it decays.
Furthermore, depending on the park's location, the environmental impact can be quite drastic. Most theme parks aren't built in urban areas where they replace existing buildings or asphalt lots. Instead, they are typically constructed in rural areas largely untouched by humans, requiring the clearing of trees, leveling of land, and overall transformation of the property. This transformation often leaves various species of birds and animals without a natural habitat. Additionally, theme parks consume vast amounts of water, straining local resources, especially in regions already facing water scarcity.

title: Animal Production - Environmental
body:
The environmental impact of animal production is detrimental to the land, air, and water and involves the unsustainable use of fossil fuels. It is one of the biggest contributors to global climate change and deforestation around the world, presenting a great threat to the world’s biodiversity.
Some of the facts are astounding. For example, animal agriculture is responsible for emitting 18% of all greenhouse gases, and this is expected to increase by 80% by the year 2050. The production of one calorie of animal protein requires ten times more fossil fuels than it takes to produce one calorie of plant protein. Factory farming is responsible for much more destruction, including chemical fumes, toxic runoff, and unsustainable water use. The animal waste that runs off these livestock lots pollutes local waterways with pesticides, herbicides, hormones, antibiotics, phosphate-rich fertilizer, and bacteria. This waste reduces clean water availability around the world and diminishes the supply of uncontaminated fish.
In addition, the massive number of animals produced on small areas of land is unsustainable and leads to reduced soil fertility and desertification, a loss of plants, and the inability to regrow lost flora. Animal production is particularly blamed for increases in greenhouse gas emissions leading to global warming. The core concerns are methane emissions stemming from the ruminal fermentation of herbivore animals and, to a lesser extent, from animal excrement. These factors also degrade water surface quality by releasing phosphate residues, trace elements (copper, zinc), and nitrates into the water. 
Yet the increase in the world population, expected to reach 11 billion by 2050 (compared to 7 billion in 2010), poses an even greater concern when combined with an expected increase in per capita meat consumption. This growth will likely exacerbate the environmental impacts of animal agriculture, making it imperative to consider sustainable alternatives.

title: Arms and defense - Corruption
body:
As the customer base for Defense companies include government customers and defense agencies, they are vulnerable to be included in bribery and corruption. Bribery in the military aviation industry has indeed been exposed in recent years, such as the case with Embraer, which paid $205 million to settle Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) charges for bribing government officials in multiple countries (Embraer). Aviation products, services and activities are subject to a number of regulators such as by the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and other regulatory bodies. The gaining of government permission can also expose the client to corruption. Furthermore, Aerospace and Defense companies often work in partnerships a number of small and non-consolidated entities. These entities have a lower level of control and oversight from their parent groups and presents higher risk of fraud and corruption.
The defence industry is a prime target for corruption because of the vast amount of money involved, global military expenditure in 2019 was estimated at more than $1.9 trillion (Expenditure). The close links between defence contracts and politics, and the notorious veil of secrecy under which the sector operates.

The impact of corruption in the arms trade is particularly serious. The value of defence contracts means that huge amounts of public money can be wasted, instead of being spent on essential services. Corruption perpetuates conflict and costs lives when troops are equipped with inadequate equipment and corrupt officials use gains from defence deals to strengthen their personal positions and undermine democracy.
More than 40 percent of all global corruption originates from the global arms trade. Poor, contradictory and weakly enforced governance systems have allowed for reporting between importing and exporting nations to become a largely private affair, devoid of meaningful scrutiny. Investigative journalism and whistleblowers have exposed many of these deals which would otherwise never have been known.

title: Automobile - Corruption
body:
The systematic prevention of bribery and corruption has reached a high level in the automotive industry. Yet potential bribery and corruption offenses are still the subject of investigations by the authorities. One topic that has gained growing attention is so-called quick savings. Quick savings – also known as nomination fees, or upfront payments – are by no means new to the automotive industry. In fact, it’s become a common phenomenon.Quick savings exist in many forms. Typically, an original equipment manufacturer (OEM) demands a one-off payment from a supplier. In return, the supplier is awarded a contract or qualified to tender or bid for a contract (so-called pay-to-play payment). There are also constellations in which the OEM demands so-called savings on current account from the supplier during a contract, to qualify for further contracts or biddings.
Depending on the case and set-up, these payments could bear a potential corruption risk. This may lead to a potential (criminal) liability – for both the person acting for the company and the company itself.
Moreover, the automobile industry is especially prone to corruption because of business practices that encourage suppliers to put up big money to win contracts from carmakers. Immense pressure on suppliers to cut costs or face losing contracts also compounds the potential for bribery and other illicit payments (Pressure to cut costs). For more than 10 years it has been common practice in contract negotiations for carmakers to demand entirely officially sums worth millions from suppliers just so they can make the short list for a contract or a follow-on contract.

title: Bloemenhandel -> Flower Trade Risk - nan
body:
Dubious traders can easily establish themselves in and around the flower auctions. The premises are poorly secured, and there is little supervision. The economic importance of being able to trade flowers quickly stands in the way of thorough checks, while the transports are attractive for drug smuggling.
This is evident from a study commissioned by several municipalities, flower auction Royal FloraHolland, and the trade association of flower traders.
However, it is suspected that the flower trade is mainly used for the transit of drugs from the Netherlands to the rest of Europe. Cocaine, for example, that enters the country via the port of Rotterdam is transported by road to other countries. Just last summer, 400 kilos of cocaine and speed were intercepted in a truck full of flowers. “The massive daily flower transports are attractive to criminals wanting to transport drugs,” the report warns. Every year, over 6 billion euros worth of flowers are exported from the Netherlands. There are shuttle services to almost every place in Europe, and cargo is rarely inspected within the European Union.
The researchers also warn of other forms of crime. Transports are also used to smuggle weapons, cigarettes, and fireworks (Special flowers). Because a lot of cash circulates in the flower sector, there is a risk that criminals use flower trading as a cover to launder their crime money. In addition, according to the report, there is fraud involving invoices, VAT rates, and consignment notes (Fin police report). Illegal labor practices are also common, with employment agencies involved in labor exploitation.
According to the report, the flower auction itself plays an important role in tackling crime. A large part of the trade takes place via the auctions of Royal FloraHolland, which connects 4,000 growers and 2,500 traders. Many traders have a small business on the grounds of one of the auctions. It is often unclear who is behind these small businesses. Traders are allowed to sublet their space at the auction. Moreover, the sites in Aalsmeer, Naaldwijk, and Rijnsburg are hardly secured and freely accessible, unlike, for example, the port or the airport. Customs, police, and military police are rarely, if ever, present there.

title: Boat & Shipping - Corruption

The shipping industry has long struggled with corruption on a wide scale. The main reason for this is the very nature of the job: frequent port calls in numerous countries around the world (each with its own set of laws and legislation), as well as multiple ship inspections and heavy bureaucracy, often leave the crew exposed to abuse of power and demands for illicit payments. Refusing to give in to demands can add huge delays and costs to the business, or worse, it can put the captain and crew at risk of harm. The most common forms of corruption at sea are bribes and facilitation payments.
As owners and managers of vessels, corruption may occur during the inspection of the vessels, frequent port calls in different countries, and in some regions, the underpaid port officials may demand payment. The large number of interactions with government officials from customs, immigration, import-export licensing, product safety and standards, agriculture, and environmental agencies mean the risk of corruption is high.
The shipping sector operates with the whole world as a workplace and depends on frequent interaction with public officials. A big challenge in the shipping industry is the frequent and persistent demands for low-value amounts demanded by public officials to facilitate port operations (‘so-called facilitation payments’). Thus, the shipping industry is exposed to high bribery risk. Also, the large number of interactions with government officials increases the risk significantly. These interactions take place in customs, immigration offices, during the import-export licensing process, while acquiring product safety or during agricultural and environmental license (permits) applications.

title: Boat & Shipping - Fraud
body:
The shipping industry and maritime commerce have seen a sharp increase in both the number and variety of fraud cases. Fraudsters are becoming increasingly ingenious in their schemes, utilizing modern technology such as computer hacking, while also employing tried-and-tested methods like document fraud. These fraudulent activities can range from receiving money for non-existent cargoes to scuttling old vessels to claim insurance, chartering "phantom ships," and substituting valuable cargoes with worthless ones.
Documentary fraud is a common issue, where a buyer might purchase cargo that is never loaded on board or buy non-existent cargo. In such cases, the fraudulent seller forges the bill of lading, using the name of a well-known shipping company or a fake company. Some maritime frauds are easily detectable, while others may remain hidden for a long time without evidence.
Visible frauds on board ships include:
Masters or chief stewards manipulating stores and victualling invoices by signing for unreceived goods and sharing the loot with suppliers.
Senior deck officers or ship's crew selling ship stores or cargo.
Senior ship engineers selling bunkers by signing for more and receiving less, manipulating shortages through cargo residues (e.g., diesel) on oil tankers.
Senior ship engineers accepting substandard machinery spares.
Senior deck officers manipulating bill of lading figures.
Ship superintendents, either alone or in liaison with senior deck officers, inflating invoices for stores, spares, or repair work not carried out in repair yards.
Cargo surveyors, in liaison with senior deck officers, manipulating daily outturn figures to boost their ratings, which is most common on bulk carriers

body:
Gambling has always attracted individuals intent on processing the proceeds of crime, making it a prime target for money laundering. This industry is characterized by the rapid movement of large sums of money, creating ample opportunities for transforming illicit funds into untraceable, clean cash. The casino and gaming sector, in particular, is considered to have an extreme risk of money laundering due to the variety, frequency, and volume of transactions. Casinos are inherently cash-intensive businesses, with the majority of transactions being cash-based. During a single visit, a customer may engage in numerous cash or electronic transactions, whether at the "buy-in" stage, during play, or at the "cash-out" stage. This routine exchange of cash for casino chips, TITO tickets, and certified checks, along with electronic transactions to and from casino deposit accounts and other jurisdictions, makes casinos an attractive target for money laundering.
Online gambling also presents significant money laundering risks. The industry is characterized by vast sums of money moving quickly and often anonymously. Sports betting, in particular, offers opportunities for both generating illegal proceeds through game fixing and for pure money laundering purposes. Criminals can use the sports betting market to launder money obtained from illegal activities. By placing wagers with illicit funds, they can receive winnings as legitimate income. Additionally, the use of multiple accounts and the difficulty in tracking transactions make it challenging for financial institutions and law enforcement agencies to detect and prevent money laundering in online gambling.
Other substantial challenges in the gambling sector include the presence of foreign exchange facilities, reduced transparency for high rollers in VIP rooms, and the use of foreign holding accounts. These factors contribute to the complexity and attractiveness of the sector for money laundering activities. For instance, foreign exchange facilities can be exploited to convert large amounts of cash into different currencies, making it harder to trace the origins of the funds. VIP rooms and high rollers often engage in large transactions that may not be scrutinized as closely, providing opportunities for illicit activities. Foreign holding accounts allow funds to be moved across jurisdictions, complicating the detection of money laundering activities.

Recent cases have highlighted how charity founders and executives have embezzled millions from their organizations, using donations meant for charitable purposes for personal expenses. This complexity can be exploited for tax evasion and fraud.
Additionally, Ultimate Beneficial Owners (UBOs) can more easily conceal themselves behind the foundation structure, using it for tax evasion. Identifying UBOs is crucial for transparency and compliance with regulations, as it helps prevent financial crimes such as money laundering and tax evasion (UBO needs to be identified). Commodity trading involves large financial transactions, which criminals can exploit to legalize illicitly sourced money. This crime often involves schemes designed to complicate the documentation of legitimate trade transactions. Such actions may include moving illicit goods, falsifying documents, misrepresenting financial transactions, and under- or over-invoicing the value of goods.
Trade mispricing practices play an increasingly important role, as anti-money laundering standards applied to other techniques for transferring illicit money across borders, particularly in the financial sector, have become more effective. Commodity trading involves complex processes and interconnected players. Under-reporting volumes or under-invoicing the value of resources sold allows the purchaser to resell them at an inflated price, with a share of the benefit potentially used to pay bribes.
This practice also enables trading companies to reduce the amount of customs duties owed to the exporting country. As trading operations are not subject to the same checks and controls as monetary flows, commodities can be easily used to circumvent anti-money laundering regulations and hide the origins of illicit funds. Proceeds of crime can be used to buy raw materials from traders who accept "dirty money" in exchange for commodities. Another practice involves traders accepting to buy raw materials of dubious origin that have been acquired illicitly. The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has emphasized the importance of addressing trade-based money laundering (TBML) risks and has provided guidelines to help identify and mitigate these risks.

This requires regular contact with customs officials, further exposing companies to high bribery risks
The sector's complexity and the involvement of multiple intermediaries, including briefcase or shell companies, add to the corruption risks. title: Consultancy services - AML
body:
The consultancy services sector faces significant anti-money laundering (AML) risks due to the nature of its operations and the broad scope of financial transactions involved. Some key AML risks in this sector include inflated receipts and invoices, where consultancy firms may arrange with legitimate vendors to provide inflated receipts in exchange for a small fee. This manipulation can involve genuine receipts showing increased quantities, prices, or additional items, or the creation of entirely new receipts. By exploiting these inflated receipts, consultancy firms can launder money generated from illegal activities.
Intercompany transactions also pose a risk when the services are not actually rendered but are used for money laundering. By transferring small amounts of money between various group companies, often with accounts at different banks, the origin of the money becomes difficult to trace. This practice can be used to launder money from criminal sources.
Criminals may use consultancy services to create complex corporate structures or trusts that obscure the ownership and control of illicit funds. These structures can make it challenging for authorities to trace the flow of illicit money. Consultants can be exploited to manipulate financial statements or evade tax obligations through false reporting. This can involve underreporting income, inflating deductions, or other deceptive practices that facilitate money laundering.
The consultancy sector often deals with high-value transactions and advisory services, which can be exploited for money laundering. The lack of transparency and the complexity of transactions can make it easier for criminals to move illegal funds through legitimate channels.

Money laundering is an old and well-known practice exercised across borders and involving various financial instruments. Since 2008, illicit users have found a new tool in cryptocurrencies, which have become a promising mechanism for those wishing to engage in money laundering. The pseudonymous nature of cryptocurrency transactions, combined with the ability to move funds quickly and across borders, makes them particularly attractive for money laundering activities.

The financial services industry on the internet, including companies trading in cryptocurrency, faces significant corruption and bribery risks. Cryptocurrencies have become popular among hackers, who often request them as a form of bribery in ransomware attacks. According to FBI statistics, in 2017, more than USD 58.3 million was stolen in cyber ransom situations, where attackers blocked access to files and demanded payment in cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, or Bitcoin Cash.
A notable example of this practice was the WannaCry ransomware attack, which required payment in Bitcoin. The WannaCry virus, which spread globally in May 2017, encrypted data on infected computers and demanded a ransom payment in Bitcoin to restore access (WannaCry).
A more recent example involves the Black Basta ransomware group. Between September 2023 and November 2024, Black Basta received between $11.4 million and $38.6 million in cryptocurrency payments to wallets under their control. This group used ransomware to encrypt victims' data and demanded payment in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin to restore access. The leaked chat logs of Black Basta revealed their operational details and the significant sums they extorted through these attacks (Black Basta).

title: Flower Trade - General
body:
Dubious traders can easily establish themselves in and around the flower auctions. The premises are poorly secured, and there is little supervision. The economic importance of being able to trade flowers quickly stands in the way of thorough checks, while the transports are attractive for drug smuggling.
This is evident from a study commissioned by several municipalities, flower auction Royal FloraHolland, and the trade association of flower traders.
However, it is suspected that the flower trade is mainly used for the transit of drugs from the Netherlands to the rest of Europe. Cocaine, for example, that enters the country via the port of Rotterdam is transported by road to other countries. Just last summer, 400 kilos of cocaine and speed were intercepted in a truck full of flowers. “The massive daily flower transports are attractive to criminals wanting to transport drugs,” the report warns. Every year, over 6 billion euros worth of flowers are exported from the Netherlands. There are shuttle services to almost every place in Europe, and cargo is rarely inspected within the European Union.
The researchers also warn of other forms of crime. Transports are also used to smuggle weapons, cigarettes, and fireworks (Special flowers). Because a lot of cash circulates in the flower sector, there is a risk that criminals use flower trading as a cover to launder their crime money. In addition, according to the report, there is fraud involving invoices, VAT rates, and consignment notes (Fin police report). Illegal labor practices are also common, with employment agencies involved in labor exploitation.
According to the report, the flower auction itself plays an important role in tackling crime. A large part of the trade takes place via the auctions of Royal FloraHolland, which connects 4,000 growers and 2,500 traders. Many traders have a small business on the grounds of one of the auctions. It is often unclear who is behind these small businesses. Traders are allowed to sublet their space at the auction. Moreover, the sites in Aalsmeer, Naaldwijk, and Rijnsburg are hardly secured and freely accessible, unlike, for example, the port or the airport. Customs, police, and military police are rarely, if ever, present there.

title: Forestry - Corruption
body:
The forestry sector, particularly in tropical and subtropical countries, is highly susceptible to illegalities and corruption due to several factors. Forestry activities often occur in large, remote areas, far from public scrutiny and official oversight, making independent checks rare and enforcement capacity low. Forest resources are valuable, but timber volumes and quality are often imprecisely known. Local forestry officers have broad discretionary powers to measure, classify, and value forest products, often with minimal supervision. Government officers overseeing high-value products are frequently on low pay, creating strong incentives for corruption. Numerous regulations and permits, often poorly designed and open to interpretation, provide opportunities for corruption. Penalties for corruption are often minimal compared to the potential high returns, making it difficult to identify and punish corrupt officials.
Corruption in the forestry sector can include illegal contracts, harvesting protected species, illegal logging, smuggling forest products, and manipulating trade to reduce tax liabilities.

body:

It requires companies placing timber on the EU market to carry out due diligence, ensuring their products come from legal sources. This includes gathering information on the supply chain, assessing risks, and taking steps to mitigate them. Non-compliance can lead to penalties, fines, or product confiscation. The EUTR is part of the EU’s broader effort to combat illegal logging and promote sustainable forestry, and it is set to evolve further under new deforestation-related regulations.

title: Healthcare - AML
body:
Money laundering can occur through healthcare insurance policies, where criminals buy single-premium policies, paying a large sum upfront, and later redeem them at a discount to receive a “clean” check from the healthcare provider. Hospitals and healthcare organizations are frequent targets for money laundering due to their strong reputations, which make suspicion less likely. Large donations are common in this industry, and healthcare companies regularly handle significant sums of money for medical procedures and equipment, making large transactions appear normal.
To protect against this risk, healthcare organizations must have strict anti-money laundering (AML) policies in place. Signs of possible money laundering include individuals filing unusually high numbers of claims, attempting to donate large sums without explaining the source, ordering large amounts of medical equipment without clear purpose, approaching distant hospitals while skipping closer ones, or refusing to disclose their identity before making a transaction.

It can occur at multiple levels—from the construction of hospitals and purchase of equipment to the supply of medicines and appointment of professionals. This widespread issue often involves a wide network of individuals, including policy-makers, ministers, contractors, suppliers, and doctors, leading to countless secret and unethical transactions.
Bribes and kickbacks are commonly used to secure government contracts, licenses, or favorable terms for supplying goods and services. Corrupt practices can also involve falsifying records or manipulating evidence to appear compliant with regulatory standards. The risk of corruption is particularly high throughout the entire healthcare chain—from policy-making and resource management to procurement and service delivery.
In many countries, corruption manifests through practices such as petty bribery, nepotism, informal payments, absenteeism, and mismanagement. Clientelism further distorts healthcare access, where personal relationships between patients and officials influence who receives care. Vulnerable areas include drug procurement and distribution, human resources, regulatory oversight, budgeting, and pricing, all of which are prone to abuse and exploitation.

Due to extensive involvement with the public sector, there are risks of corruption and bribery while obtaining licenses and bidding on tenders. body:
The infrastructure and construction industry faces significant environmental risks at all phases of large infrastructure projects. These risks can arise during the construction phase, as well as during the operation and maintenance of large-scale infrastructure. Consequently, they need to be managed throughout all stages of the asset ownership lifecycle. With the development of strict environmental legislation in many countries, there are defined requirements for construction companies and operators to assess potential environmental impacts and manage their business activities accordingly.
Operations associated with infrastructure asset management, such as wastewater treatment and the maintenance of new or existing facilities, are included in these requirements. Currently, this type of environmental risk may be managed through the use of “sudden and accidental” pollution coverage provided by some forms of public liability insurance. Additionally, the risk of causing physical damage to the environment during the construction and operation of infrastructure has the potential to incur costs for restoration and rehabilitation.

https://ijpiel.com/index.php/2023/04/10/assessing-the-environmental-impact-of-infrastructure-projects/

title: Infrastructure and construction Industry - Fraud
body:
The presence of fraud (and corruption) in the infrastructure and construction industry can take many forms. Especially during the construction phase of infrastructure projects, fraudulent activities often occur through inflated invoices for hiring equipment and labor, pilferage of inventory and scrap material, inflated costs for earthwork, and collusion between vendors and employees to inflate quotations.
Fraud in large public construction projects results in taxpayers not getting value for money and undermine the profitability of legitimate construction companies. This enriches dishonest individuals and organized crime. The complexity of construction projects, with their numerous contractors and subcontractors, creates opportunities for fraudulent activities at every stage.

title: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only - AML
sector: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only
body:
The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has identified certain insurance activities carried out online as being exposed to the threat of money laundering. Insurance products, particularly life insurance, provide a very attractive and simple means of laundering money. In 2018, drug traffickers allegedly purchased more than 200 online life insurance policies through brokers, naming cartel members and family members as beneficiaries. Policies were paid for using wire transfers purchased with drug money. Additionally, criminals used dirty money to purchase general insurance policies to insure high-value goods. These goods had also been purchased with dirty money. They subsequently made fraudulent claims against the policies, effectively laundering their money several times through buying furniture, then buying a policy, and finally receiving a “clean” cheque from their insurance company when they made a claim. Therefore, insurance activities performed online have a high risk of money laundering.

https://msbdocs.com/kyc/money-laundering-insurance/

title: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only - Fraud
sector: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only
body:
Online insurance companies offer more flexibility and cheaper premium plans, which attract individuals more than offline companies. The online insurance sector does not require brokers and provides direct access to the company. However, this easy access makes the sector vulnerable to fraud risks. Organized criminals can exploit online companies by inflating claims, misrepresenting facts on insurance applications, submitting claims for injuries or damage that never occurred, and staging accidents due to the flexibility and accessibility of online platforms.

The rise of online insurance has made the industry a prime target for fraud. Fraudsters can create multiple accounts and insure gadgets or electronics, then find ways to exploit their policies. The insurance sector has become more susceptible to financial crime risk, given its size, diversity, complexity of product offerings, and range of delivery channels. Digital application processes make it easier to commit insurance application fraud, such as opening policies for fictitious beneficiaries or falsifying application information to reduce premiums.

https://seon.io/resources/online-insurance-fraud/

title: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only - Operational
sector: Insurance activities taking place on the internet only
body:
Insurance activities taking place on the internet are particularly vulnerable to operational risks, especially external fraud. Life insurance fraud can involve faking death to claim life insurance, with fraudsters sometimes reappearing years later, claiming a loss of memory. A notable example is former British Government minister John Stonehouse, who went missing in 1974 from a beach in Miami. He was discovered living under an assumed name in Australia, extradited to Britain, and jailed for seven years for fraud, theft, and forgery.
Car insurance is also prone to fraud, with fraud rings or groups faking traffic deaths or staging collisions to make false or exaggerated claims and collect insurance money. These rings may involve insurance claims adjusters and other individuals who create phony police reports to process claims.

title: Intellectual Property (IP) - Integrity
body:
The exploitation of intellectual property (IP) rights and licensing increases corruption risk, as facilitation payments may be made to obtain patents. Tax evasion risks, seen as a criminal offense, also lead to anti-money laundering (AML) risk. Companies exploiting IP rights can use licensing (royalty) payments as intercompany transactions with the sole purpose of shifting profits to low-tax jurisdictions (ACAMS, Sanction Scanner, FIAU Malta).

Other risks are related to intellectual property crime, which occurs when someone manufactures, sells, or distributes counterfeit or pirated goods, such as patents, trademarks, industrial designs, or literary and artistic works, for commercial gain (ICE, DHS).

title: International & Local Sports Associations - Corruption
body:
Sport is increasingly big business and, crucially, associated with big business, thus providing opportunities and motivation for corrupt practices. As sport has gained in popularity, so too has the amount of money involved in various games and in building associated infrastructure, especially for events such as the Olympic Games and the football World Cup. The vast amount of money flowing through these bodies, coupled with the financially significant decisions they make, often at the highest levels of politics and in the absence of best practices for governance, creates settings amenable to corrupt practices. For example, on April 10, 2020, U.S. prosecutors charged former Fox Sports executives Carlos Martinez and Hernan Lopez with bribing FIFA officials to secure broadcasting rights in South America. The case also involves allegations of bribes influencing the selection of Russia and Qatar as hosts for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, which both countries deny (FIFA Scandal).
The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) highlights that the bidding for and awarding of major sports events present unique corruption risks, both for the bidding cities and countries and for the international sport organizations that select the hosts. The key risks relate to the various stages of the bidding and selection processes.

title: International & Local Sports Associations - Fraud
body:
In organizing sporting events, including the delivery of related infrastructure, there are ever-present risks of inefficiencies, corruption, and serious misconduct, such as fraud. The need to meet tight deadlines and manage the large resources required for infrastructure projects indeed exposes sporting events to financial and reputational risks stemming from corrupt or fraudulent practices. Fraud usually occurs through irregular documentary practices. One such practice is falsifying supporting evidence linked to qualification requirements, such as commercial registration or financial capacity. Fraud can also mask poor performance and corrupt practices, such as billing for works never performed, inflated billing for goods and services, and failing to meet contract specifications. When performed by project officials, it includes diverting project assets and setting up front companies to create the illusion of competition (Play by the Rules, UNODC).

title: International Insurance activities - AML
body:
Money laundering in the international insurance sector aims to break the connection between illicit money and the predicate offense that generates the funds. There are several reasons why criminals tend to use the insurance sector as a vehicle for laundering their illicit funds. These include the size of the industry, the diversity in its products, and ease of availability. Other reasons for utilizing insurance companies for money laundering are the difficulty in detecting illicit funds from large investments due to high transaction levels and the good return on investment.

The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has identified the insurance sector as vulnerable to money laundering due to its flexible nature and the large amounts of money involved in transactions. Criminals often exploit insurance products, such as life insurance, by overpaying premiums, surrendering policies prematurely, or making fictitious claims to cycle illicit funds back as legitimate payouts. Additionally, reinsurance arrangements can be manipulated, where criminals establish offshore entities to overpay for coverage, channeling dirty money into reinsurers that eventually reach the primary insurance companies. The insurance sector's vulnerability to money laundering is further exacerbated by the difficulty in detecting illicit funds from large investments due to high transaction levels and the good return on investment.



Links:
https://complyadvantage.com/insights/anti-money-laundering-insurance-sector/

title: International Insurance activities - Corruption
body:
The difficulty for insurers is that many of the overseas markets in which they see the most exciting opportunities for growth are territories where they are more likely to be vulnerable to problems with corruption. There is a growing number of corruption and fraud in insurance, especially when operated internationally. For example, in motor insurance, corrupt customers can stage a car accident beforehand. This usually occurs when the book value of a person's car is worth more than the actual car, as the person will attempt to get money for the car through insurance.

A growing concern in international insurance operations is the rise in fraud cases. In motor insurance, a common fraudulent activity involves customers staging car accidents to claim insurance payouts. This typically occurs when the book value of a vehicle exceeds its actual market value, incentivizing the owner to orchestrate an accident to receive a higher insurance settlement. Such staged accidents are not only illegal but also pose significant safety risks to the public.

title: International Insurance activities - Operational
body:
International insurance activities face significant operational risks, particularly due to the lack of personal contact, as insurance brokers rarely visit a client’s home and many consumers prefer to handle their business via the internet. This lack of personal interaction makes the sector vulnerable to fraud risks. Insurance fraud can occur in many ways, starting with the false preparation of insurance contracts or providing false or incomplete information in insurance claims. Fraudsters may apply for claims based on incorrect circumstances, inflate the value of insured property, or report fictitious injuries from accidents, all with the intent of obtaining unjustified benefits.

Operational risk in the insurance sector encompasses a wide range of events and actions, including fraud, human error, accounting errors, legal actions, and system failures. Fraudulent activities in insurance can take various forms, such as exaggerated claims, falsified medical history, post-dated policies, and faked death or kidnapping.

title: International Trade - AML
body:
International trade has a potential risk for money laundering, known as Trade-Based Money Laundering (TBML). Criminals can use legitimate trade to disguise their criminal proceeds from illegal sources. Regulatory officials often lack data on the actual prices of products being imported and exported and are unaware if the declared prices of goods by traders are close to actual prices on world markets. Thus, trade invoicing is a common way to launder illicit money by criminals in international trade. As a result, the illicit flow of money remains undetected through the international trading system.

title: Involving international & local sports - Tax
body:
The sport sector is also vulnerable to tax evasion risk. Sport players with an excellent reputation, and sometimes others as well, get the chance of concluding so-called “image contracts” with companies that generally have their registered office abroad. These contracts take advantage of the “rights to the player’s image” and are a tool to exploit personal appearances by the player as part of broad publicity campaigns but could represent vulnerabilities in respect to tax evasion and money laundering activities. Image rights contracts allow players to exploit their likeness for commercial value, such as through sponsorship and endorsement activities. However, these contracts can be used to minimize tax liability by setting up image rights companies (IRCs) in low-tax jurisdictions. This practice can lead to significant tax savings but also raises concerns about tax evasion (Accountancy Age, Mills & Reeve). High-profile cases like Cristiano Ronaldo’s $21 million tax evasion fine in 2019 highlight the ongoing scrutiny of tax fraud in the sport (Tax evasion footballer).

title: IT Services - AML
body:
Advances in information technology and the rising demand for real-time payments and transfers are making it easier for money launderers to perform criminal activities. An example of how money laundering can be facilitated through IT services is a variation of the Internet scam known as phishing. In this scam, criminals obtain a victim's bank account number under the pretense of depositing fictitious lottery winnings or international inheritance. They then make multiple deposits into the victim's bank account with the stipulation that a portion of the money must be transferred to another account, effectively laundering the funds.
Money laundering through IT services often involves exploiting peer-to-peer (P2P) money transfer platforms, which offer speed, anonymity, and global reach. Criminals use these platforms to obscure the origins of their illicit gains by transferring funds between multiple accounts across different platforms and countries, creating a complex web of transactions that is difficult to trace. Additionally, the use of cryptocurrencies in P2P platforms adds another layer of complexity to money laundering activities.

title: IT Services - Corruption
body:
IT services have led to a number of corruption offenses, including bribery, funds embezzlement, procurement violations, and conflicts of interest. Corruption and bribery in the IT service industry are high because staff have access to valued resources and to those who will pay for them. These valued resources could include the provision of a service, legal permission to undertake some activity, or information of value stored in their IT facilities. IT service providers have the skills, confidence, and autonomy to make decisions about the provision of these resources. Therefore, they can be bribed to provide confidential information stored in their systems or to destroy information that may be incriminating to a certain party. They can also be bribed to use their skills to hack into people's private bank accounts, social media accounts, emails, etc.
Abuse of IT corruption mainly occurs where financial interests are at stake, as well as in cases where IT abuse serves only the interests of a public official. Moreover, in order to operate IT services, an operational license is involved, which involves government officials, thereby leading to a bribery risk.

title: IT Services - Cyber Crime
body:
Activities related to ICT and datacenters are vulnerable to cybercrime. Services can be used for illegal activities, and sensitive data can be hacked by criminals. Additionally, companies themselves can abuse their knowledge and access to sensitive data for their own benefit, commissioned by third parties, or because employees are bribed by criminal organizations.
In combination with high-risk countries, there is an increased risk due to espionage by foreign intelligence services or foreign competitors. According to the Cyber Security Assessment Netherlands (CSAN), digital threats are a permanent fixture, and the scale of the threat posed by nation-state actors continues to grow. Countries like China, Iran, and Russia have offensive cyber programs against Western countries to obtain illegally economically valuable data and achieve geopolitical objectives, potentially causing social disruption.
The risks can be partly mitigated because independent institutes regularly audit the services of the ICT provider. Moreover, the ICT provider has accredited its global standards with ISO certifications. It also has a code of conduct describing corporate governance.

These risks can lead to financial loss, disruption, or damage to an organization's reputation due to failures in its information technology systems. title: Jewelry and diamond business - AML
body:
The jewelry and diamond business is particularly attractive to money launderers due to the ease with which illegal money can be used to purchase expensive assets that are easily resold or transported across borders. This makes it challenging for law enforcement to detect illegal movements of funds. Diamonds, in particular, are highly susceptible to misuse in money laundering schemes because their small size and high value facilitate concealment and transport. This makes diamonds one of the most vulnerable gems and jewels to money laundering activities. The use of diamonds as a form of currency is widespread, as they are difficult to trace and can provide anonymity in transactions. Trade-Based Money Laundering (TBML) further exacerbates the vulnerability of the diamond trade to various money laundering techniques.

title: Jewelry and diamond business - Corruption
body:
The diamond industry continues to be tainted by links between diamonds and corruption. Governments earn significant revenues from the diamond industry, both through taxation and profit-sharing arrangements. However, they often fail to reinvest these funds in local communities, which can be attributed to corruption and bribery. This helps explain why governments fail to invest their diamond revenues productively, making diamonds a significant source of corruption in many countries.
Recent developments, such as the bankruptcy of Swiss jeweler De Grisogono following the "Luanda Leaks" scandal, illustrate the ongoing challenges and the need for stringent anti-corruption measures in the diamond industry (Luanda leaks).

title: Jewelry and diamond business - Environmental
body:
Diamond mining has caused significant environmental destruction around the world. The techniques used in diamond mining often leave damaging effects on the earth, which can sometimes be irreversible. Improper diamond mining practices may lead to soil erosion and deforestation, and in some parts of the world, it has forced local populations to relocate. In extreme cases, diamond mining can cause entire ecosystems to collapse, thereby posing a very high environmental risk for the diamond and jewelry business.

The environmental impact of diamond mining includes soil erosion, land disturbances, deforestation, and water pollution. These activities can alter the course of waterways and impact biodiversity, leading to long-term ecological damage. Additionally, the high energy consumption and emissions associated with diamond mining contribute to its environmental footprint.

title: Law firms and lawyers - AML
body:
Professionals such as lawyers play an important role in helping clients manage their financial affairs. However, they can also be misused by criminals seeking to launder illicit funds. Two major attractions for money launderers are lawyers' expertise in legal matters and the protection of client confidentiality. By abusing these privileges, some legal professionals may assist individuals and organized criminal groups in concealing the origins of illegal proceeds.
Lawyers can become involved in money laundering by advising on methods of transferring funds, holding large sums on behalf of clients, and channeling illicit money through their accounts. The attorney-client privilege, which ensures confidentiality, can be exploited to shield illegal activities from scrutiny. Lawyers often manage trust accounts on behalf of their clients, which can be used to temporarily hold illicit funds before they are laundered through subsequent transactions.

title: Law firms and lawyers - Corruption
body:
The potential for some lawyers and law firms to abuse the attorney-client privilege, combined with weak industry-wide anti-corruption standards and inadequate internal policies and controls, makes the legal profession vulnerable to corruption risks. The attorney-client privilege, which ensures confidentiality, can be exploited to shield corrupt activities from scrutiny. Some lawyers lack awareness and knowledge of anti-corruption provisions, which can lead to inadvertent or deliberate engagement in corrupt activities.
Weak internal controls within law firms further exacerbate these risks. Effective internal controls are essential for safeguarding assets and ensuring financial reporting accuracy, but many law firms fail to implement robust systems. The legal profession's susceptibility to corruption is also heightened by the pressure to turn a profit for clients, which can undermine ethical standards and integrity.

title: Luxury and beauty products - AML
body:
The luxury goods sector can be a prime conduit for laundering the proceeds of criminal activity. For the corrupt, the luxury sector is more than just a money laundering vehicle. Money launderers often purchase high-value luxury goods that are easily transportable. By selling high-end items, criminals can attach extra money or price to the transaction, use paperwork to document the interaction, and effectively clean the money. Additionally, they may use intermediaries or middlemen to help launder the money.
The allure of luxury goods lies in their physical portability and potential for resale in secondary markets, making them attractive tools for criminals looking to legitimize illicit proceeds through legitimate transactions. Luxury goods such as watches, cars, jewelry, yachts, and art are often targeted by money launderers because they can serve as relatively easily acquired and transferable assets. These items can be used for the placement, layering, and integration stages of money laundering schemes.

https://fintelegram.com/money-laundering-in-the-luxury-goods-market-a-comprehensive-analysis/

title: Luxury and beauty products - Corruption
body:
Luxury goods typically, although not always, appear at the end-point or ‘integration’ part of a money-laundering operation, after the placement of illicit gains into the financial system and the layering process, whether that happens through offshore accounts or by other means. Moreover, luxury goods are used to facilitate corrupt transactions and launder dirty money. In order to run a luxury and beauty products line, the company has to procure an operating license from government officials, which involves a risk of bribery to ignore certain criteria.
The luxury goods sector is particularly susceptible to corruption and bribery due to the high value and desirability of its products. Bribes can take many forms, including luxury goods themselves, which can be used to influence officials and secure favorable treatment. The desire for an affluent lifestyle among corrupt elites often drives the demand for high-end items, further entrenching the link between luxury goods and corruption.

https://www.whitecase.com/insight-our-thinking/high-value-high-risk-bribery-corruption-and-fraud-threats-luxury-goods-sector

title: Luxury and beauty products - Operational
body:
Luxury products tend to attract a relatively small, yet highly influential crowd of customers who buy based on quality and service. Unfortunately, those same items tend to attract fraudsters looking to pull a low-effort, high-profit scam. Luxury designer goods like high-end handbags are exceptionally popular targets for online fraud. These items are very easy to resell due to their popularity and broad appeal among consumers around the world, plus they are small and easy to ship. This means retailers are hit both ways—fraudsters steal their products, then use the stolen goods to compete against those same retailers in the marketplace.
Recently, the reputations and profitability of luxury goods retailers have come under threat from a new danger: counterfeit products. These unauthorized replicas of real products, often referred to as "super fakes," are becoming increasingly sophisticated and harder to distinguish from genuine items. The rise of counterfeit goods has intensified concerns over brand authenticity and consumer trust, posing significant operational risks for businesses in the luxury sector.

title: Manufacturing Industry - Corruption
body:
Although the manufacturing industry is not considered high risk, it still carries some corruption risks. According to the ACFE report "Global Study on Occupational Fraud and Abuse" in 2018, the greatest number of cases in the study occurred in the banking and financial services, manufacturing, and government and public administration sectors. The report stated that corruption poses a significant risk to manufacturing, ranking it as the second most corrupted industry after energy.
Manufacturers need production facilities, which require numerous licenses and permits and are subject to different regulations in every territory they operate, such as environmental, occupational safety, and health regulations. This regulatory complexity can lead to bribery of officials to overlook certain required criteria. Companies in the manufacturing sector often engage in significant import and export activities, necessitating regular contact with customs officials. This frequent interaction increases the risk of corruption and bribery in order to facilitate smoother operations.

title: Manufacturing Industry - Fraud
body:
The manufacturing sector is often one of the most vulnerable sectors, exposed to the risk of fraud and corruption. Some of the most recent frauds in the manufacturing sector that have caused significant losses to companies have been due to inferior product quality triggering product recalls, warranty claims fraud, and intellectual property infringement. In some cases, these have also resulted in criminal or civil actions due to regulatory and statutory violations. Additionally, one of the other most common frauds in this sector is inventory fraud, related to the theft or misuse of stocks, which continues to be a cause of concern.
Furthermore, the manufacturing sector carries a somewhat high risk of fraud. The industry itself makes it susceptible to non-cash frauds such as stealing goods and materials by employees, as well as intellectual property like trade secrets and technology. The complexity of manufacturing processes and the high value of materials and products involved create opportunities for fraudsters to exploit weaknesses in internal controls.

title: Manufacturing Industry - Environmental
body:
The manufacturing industry can significantly impact both human health and the environment. One of the major concerns is the release of pollutants into the air, which can cause serious damage to environmental and public health. In addition to air pollution, the industry places heavy pressure on natural resources through excessive or unmonitored use of water and energy. Manufacturing processes contribute to a variety of environmental hazards, including atmospheric emissions of pollutants, soil contamination, greenhouse gas emissions, as well as the release of dust and noise pollution.
Furthermore, the manufacturing industry involves a wide range of operational practices that carry unique safety risks for employees. Working with manufacturing machinery exposes workers to several hazards. Machines with gears, sprockets, pulleys, and rotating shafts present risks of entanglement, while areas where two hard surfaces move together pose a threat of crush injuries. Equipment with sharp edges or scissoring actions can cause cuts, punctures, or even severed limbs. Cables and hoses around machinery increase the risk of trip-and-fall accidents.. To mitigate these dangers, employers should install appropriate machine guards and ensure that machines are properly turned off during maintenance activities.
Beyond occupational hazards, manufacturing processes also generate significant environmental risks through the production of air, liquid, and solid waste. Activities such as metalworking produce welding slags, dust, powders, and metal chips, which often contain various oxides. Harmful emissions released during operational processes further contaminate the air, exacerbating the industry's impact on environmental health.

title: Meida and entertainment - Corruption
body:

In some countries, the government controls or owns all media outlets, including newspapers, television, and radio. Additionally, certain governments regulate the licensing of cable and satellite networks, as well as radio and television broadcasting. This control extends to various aspects of media operations, making the industry susceptible to corruption.
Moreover, companies in the M&E sector often use third-party intermediaries to facilitate interactions with government officials, especially in developing or third-world countries. These intermediaries can sometimes engage in corrupt practices to expedite processes or secure favorable outcomes. Media companies frequently contact government officials for production permits, transporting equipment to international locations, and other day-to-day operations, further exposing them to corruption risks.

title: Meida and entertainment - Environmental
body:
The Media and Entertainment (M&E) industry has a notable environmental impact. In 2007, media technologies and production accounted for approximately 3% of greenhouse gases emitted globally. This significant contribution to greenhouse gas emissions highlights the industry's role in environmental degradation.
The use of plastics in creating media and communication technologies poses severe health risks. These plastics can cause brain, liver, kidney, and stomach cancer when improperly disposed of, releasing harmful substances into the environment. The production and disposal of these plastics contribute to environmental pollution, affecting both ecosystems and human health. Additionally, the manufacturing processes involved in media technologies often lead to the release of toxic substances. For example, the production of electronic devices involves the use of hazardous chemicals and materials, which can contaminate soil and water sources. The improper disposal of electronic waste, or e-waste, further exacerbates these environmental issues, as it releases carcinogenic dioxins and hydrochloric acid into the environment.
