https://feu-journal.eu/issues/issue-4/sustainability-in-the-media-and-entertainment-industry/

title: Media publishing /Social media Publishing - AML
body:
Social media has an increasingly dominant role in recruiting people to facilitate money laundering, whether they do so knowingly or unknowingly. Several recent reports have highlighted young people being recruited as money mules through social media platforms. Unwitting mules are also being recruited through social media offers of fake jobs or initiatives to make extra money. These schemes often involve criminals posing as legitimate employers or offering seemingly attractive opportunities, which can deceive young people into participating in money laundering activities. The allure of quick cash and the perceived legitimacy of these offers make social media a fertile ground for recruiting money mules.



Links:
https://amluae.com/adverse-media-and-social-media-checks-under-aml-compliance/

title: Media publishing /Social media Publishing - Corruption
body:
Corruption can occur in various forms in the media publishing landscape. Types of corruption in the media can vary from the abuse of position when hiring or firing staff or making editorial decisions, thereby influencing media coverage. Although there is limited research available on corruption in the media, there is enough evidence that corruption can manifest itself through various forms. Journalists, editors, and media houses can be bribed to publish favorable stories or to refrain from publishing damaging ones, often by prominent figures trying to create a good reputation for themselves.
Giving gifts and placing advertisements in the media can be alternative ways to influence media reporting in favor of private or political interests. Journalists tend to be especially vulnerable to this form of corruption in developing countries where their salaries are often very low. This type of media corruption often results from widespread collusion between journalists and public relations and publishing organizations. Types of corruption in the media vary from bribery in the form of cash for news, staged or fake news, gift giving, concealed advertisement, and advertisements to nepotism, and media capture by vested private or political interests.



Links:
https://www.aalep.eu/fighting-corruption-media

title: Media publishing /Social media Publishing - Environmental
body:
The best estimates suggest that media technologies and production accounted for 3% of greenhouse gases emitted around the world in 2007. Ever since the development of print, the media have drawn upon, created, and emitted dangerous substances, producing multi-generational risks for ecosystems and workers. For example, poisonous solvents, inks, fumes, dust, and wastewater have been byproducts of printing newspapers for two centuries. The use of plastics to create media and communication technologies can cause brain, liver, kidney, and stomach cancer, while disposing of them releases carcinogenic dioxins and hydrochloric acid into the environment. This causes significant damage to both the environment and human health.



Links:
https://sites.evergreen.edu/climatechange/wp-content/uploads/sites/584/2021/01/Greening-the-Media-Intro-Ch.1.pdf

title: Media publishing /Social media Publishing - Operational
body:
Several high-profile cases of hackers representing themselves as organizations or companies have highlighted the potential of social media to perpetrate fraud that is harder to deal with because information goes “viral” so quickly in an online and wireless world. These cases have had serious consequences. For instance, hackers representing themselves on Twitter as the Associated Press posted a false story about a bombing at the White House, which caused the Dow Jones Industrial Average to fall about 150 points in a matter of minutes, representing approximately $150 billion in market value. Another significant risk associated with the media sector is the violation of privacy. In some highly publicized cases, social media sites have experienced security breaches in which confidential user information was shared publicly. These breaches expose users to various risks, including identity theft and financial fraud. The massive stores of personal data that social media platforms collect and retain are particularly vulnerable to hacking, scraping, and data breaches, especially if platforms fail to implement critical security measures and access restrictions.



Links:
https://digitalprivacy.ieee.org/publications/topics/privacy-risks-and-social-media

title: Microfinance Industry - AML
body:
The microfinance industry faces significant money laundering risks due to its cash-intensive nature. Providers of loans could exploit the system to launder their cash by using befriended borrowers or making special agreements with these borrowers. Microfinance institutions (MFIs) often operate in regions with limited regulatory oversight, making them vulnerable to financial crimes. Money laundering in the microfinance sector can occur through various methods, including the placement, layering, and integration of illicit funds.



Links:
https://amlwatcher.com/blog/navigating-the-money-laundering-challenge-in-the-microfinance-realm/

title: Mining and Metal Industry - AML
body:
Mining operations are frequently established in remote jurisdictions that require large volumes of cash to pay for goods and services, including the salaries of local staff. The nature of cash makes it an easily misappropriated asset, which is often exacerbated by a lack of defined or adequate systems to record and monitor cash movements. The mining and metal industry is particularly vulnerable to money laundering due to these factors.



Links:
https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2023/04/mining-money-laundering-risks

title: Mining and Metal Industry - Corruption
body:
Mining activities often require licenses from the government, leading to frequent interactions with government officials. In countries with high levels of corruption, this increases the risk of bribery and fraud for companies operating in this sector. One of the significant challenges is the use of agents and consultants by multinational companies to negotiate on their behalf. These intermediaries can be difficult to control, and they may receive bonuses for securing licenses, which can incentivize corrupt practices. The lack of direct oversight over these individuals further exacerbates the risk of bribery and fraud.
The volatility of raw material prices makes procurement a critical area prone to corruption. Hidden bribes or benefits can be reflected in inflated material prices, substandard materials, and variations to the original contract. This not only affects the financial health of the company but also its reputation and compliance with legal and ethical standards.



Links:
https://www.u4.no/topics/oil-gas-and-mining/basics

title: Mining and Metal Industry - Environmental
body:
The environmental and geological damage and pollution that might occur during the mining, transport and storage of the products. Mining has the potential to cause a range of environmental and social risks, including (but not limited to) the following: water use and availability, contamination of land and water, emissions to air, noise, large footprint/land take, extensive rehabilitation required at mine closure, health and safety of workers, security, resettlement (physical and economic) and impacts on local.



Links:
https://www.unepfi.org/themes/climate-change/climate-risks-in-the-metals-and-mining-sector/#:~:text=Mining%20and%20metals%20are%20some,soil%2C%20water%20and%20air%20pollution.

title: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange) - AML
sector: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange)
body:
The simplicity and certainty of transactions in the money remitters (MR) and bureau de change (currency exchange, CE) sectors, along with their low thresholds and often less stringent customer identification rules compared to banks, make these sectors attractive vehicles for criminal and terrorist funds to enter the financial system for money laundering (ML) purposes. The reduced possibilities for verification of customers' identification in MR and CE sectors compared to other financial institutions make it easier for illicit funds to be laundered. The straightforward nature of MR/CE transactions allows for quick and easy movement of funds, which can be exploited for ML purposes. In the CE sector, once money has been exchanged, it becomes difficult to trace its origin, further complicating efforts to prevent ML. Currency exchanges, often being small businesses, are more susceptible to takeover by criminals who can use them to launder money.



Links:
https://www.fatf-gafi.org/en/publications/Methodsandtrends/Moneylaunderingthroughmoneyremittanceandcurrencyexchangeproviders.html

title: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange) - Corruption
sector: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange)
body:
In some countries, money remittance (MR) providers must be registered or licensed to operate in the money remittance and currency exchange (MR/CE) business. This requirement exposes the industry to bribery risks when dealing with government officials. The need for various licenses and permits can lead to situations where MR providers may feel pressured to bribe officials to expedite processes or secure favorable outcomes.



Links:
https://www.skadden.com/insights/publications/2025/02/antibribery-and-corruption-risks-remain

title: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange) - Fraud
sector: Money remitters and bureau de change (currency exchange)
body:
The availability of stolen credentials, advanced cyber tools, and full exploits for sale or rent on the dark web has made it easier for less technically astute individuals to commit fraud. With hundreds of billions of dollars sent abroad annually through money remittance systems, fraudsters have been quick to capitalize on the rapid adoption of money transfer technology, exploiting opportunities to take over accounts or utilize stolen identity credentials. Without tight fraud protection, the reputation of this industry could be irreparably damaged by the negative associations of fraud events.



Links:
https://www.bankrate.com/personal-finance/common-scams-associated-with-money-exchange/

title: Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) - AML
body:
Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) can sometimes operate as a pyramid scheme, where a product is used as a cover for the transfer of money. Sellers are required to buy products from the company, which they may use themselves but are also meant to sell. This structure can be exploited by criminals to launder money from illegal activities by starting an MLM chain and pretending their income is derived from product sales.
In such schemes, the emphasis is often on recruitment rather than the actual sale of products, making it easier for money launderers to introduce illicit funds into the financial system. The layering process involves shuffling the money around to create distance between it and the perpetrators, while the integration stage brings the laundered money back to the perpetrators as legitimate income.



Links:
https://consumer.ftc.gov/articles/multi-level-marketing-businesses-pyramid-schemes

title: Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) - Corruption
body:
Regulators have determined that a multi-level marketing (MLM) structure is not fraudulent if the company makes most of its profits from selling products or services to end-user consumers, rather than primarily recruiting new sales agents and requiring those agents to purchase their own inventory. This distinction is crucial in differentiating legitimate MLM businesses from pyramid schemes, which rely heavily on recruitment and often lack substantial product sales to genuine consumers. 
However, the MLM industry is not without its corruption risks. For instance, some MLM companies may engage in corrupt practices to secure favorable regulatory treatment or to avoid scrutiny from authorities. This can involve bribing officials to overlook regulatory violations or to expedite the approval of licenses and permits.mAdditionally, the hierarchical nature of MLM structures can create opportunities for corruption within the organization itself. Leaders at the top of the pyramid may exploit their positions to extract additional payments from lower-level participants or to manipulate sales data to inflate their earnings.



Links:
https://www.ftc.gov/business-guidance/resources/business-guidance-concerning-multi-level-marketing

title: Narcotics - AML
body:
The practice of money laundering by narcotics dealers is becoming increasingly diverse, creative, integrated, globalized, and complex. Money laundering is essential for narcotics dealers to legitimize the proceeds of their illegal activities and integrate them into the financial system. Narcotics dealers employ various sophisticated techniques to launder money, such as using shell companies, trade-based money laundering, and cryptocurrencies. They also exploit financial institutions, real estate, and high-value goods to move and clean their money. The global nature of the narcotics trade means that money laundering operations often span multiple countries, making it challenging for authorities to track and intercept illicit financial flows.



Links:
https://www.sanctionscanner.com/blog/leveraging-aml-procedures-to-combat-illicit-trafficking-in-narcotic-drugs-196

title: Narcotics - Corruption
body:
The narcotics trade, particularly involving hard drugs, is fraught with corruption and bribery risks due to the illegal nature of the supply chain. The manufacture, preparation, processing, sale, delivery, supply, and transport of these substances are prohibited, making the entire supply chain illicit. This illegality necessitates various administrative tasks by doctors and pharmacists to justify the use of certain substances, which in turn increases the risk of corruption and extortion.
In the context of medical marijuana, there have been numerous instances where clients have paid bribes to officials to obtain authorization for dispensaries. For example, in Garden City, Michigan, individuals were indicted for bribing city officials to secure permits for a medical marijuana dispensary. Other medical institutions have been known to engage in bribery to obtain medical marijuana licenses. A notable case involved the former Michigan House Speaker, who admitted to accepting $110,000 in bribes to influence the issuance of medical marijuana licenses.



Links:
https://www.u4.no/publications/approaches-to-corruption-in-drug-management/pdf

title: Narcotics - Environmental
body:
The narcotics industry, particularly cannabis cultivation, indeed has the potential to produce significant waste. Estimates suggest that each cultivation site could generate around 100,000 pounds of waste, including leaves, trimmed stems, post-extracted plant material, and chemical waste. Proper management of this waste is crucial to prevent environmental contamination and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.
Cannabis cultivation also has a notable impact on carbon emissions. Indoor cannabis growing is particularly energy-intensive, with lighting, heating, cooling, and dehumidification contributing significantly to greenhouse gas emissions. Research indicates that growing an ounce of cannabis indoors can emit as much carbon as burning a full tank of gas. This highlights the substantial environmental footprint of the industry. Moreover, it is estimated that cannabis production accounts for approximately 1% of total energy usage in the United States. This high energy consumption underscores the need for sustainable practices within the industry to mitigate its environmental impact.



Links:
https://mgmagazine.com/business/growing-horticulture/proper-cannabis-waste-disposal-stay-compliant-legal/

title: Narcotics - Fraud
body:
Legal drug fraud is a significant concern in the narcotics industry, manifesting in various forms of internal and external fraud. Internal fraud occurs when physicians prescribe narcotics under false pretenses, often because drug manufacturers have paid them to dispense their products. This unethical practice is supported by evidence showing that doctors who receive payments from pharmaceutical companies tend to prescribe those companies' drugs more frequently. Drug pricing fraud is another issue, where physicians prescribe expensive medications, sometimes unnecessarily, to profit from the receipts.
Patients can also engage in external fraud by forging prescriptions to obtain narcotics. This type of fraud involves creating fake prescriptions or altering legitimate ones to access more drugs than prescribed. There have been instances where individuals pose as doctors to gain access to free samples of medical narcotics provided by drug manufacturers.



Links:
https://www.propublica.org/article/doctors-prescribe-more-of-a-drug-if-they-receive-money-from-a-pharma-company-tied-to-it

title: Nuclear power exploitation - Corruption
body:
Widespread corruption in the nuclear industry indeed has profound social and political consequences, primarily due to the erosion of public trust in companies, governments, and energy systems. High-profile cases, such as the bribery scandal involving FirstEnergy in Ohio, illustrate the extent of corruption. In this case, FirstEnergy was implicated in a $61 million bribery scheme to secure a $1.5 billion bailout for its nuclear plants. This scandal not only undermined public confidence but also highlighted the vulnerabilities within the regulatory and political systems.
Similarly, in South Carolina, the former CEO of SCANA, Kevin B. Marsh, was sentenced to federal prison for his role in a conspiracy to commit mail and wire fraud. This involved misleading regulators and the public about the progress of a nuclear project to secure rate increases and tax credits. These incidents demonstrate how corruption can lead to significant financial and social repercussions, affecting not just the immediate stakeholders but the broader public as well.



Links:
https://www.crikey.com.au/2024/06/21/nuclear-power-corruption/

title: Nuclear power exploitation - Environmental
body:
A major environmental concern related to nuclear power is the creation of radioactive wastes, including uranium mill tailings, spent reactor fuel, and other radioactive materials. These wastes can remain radioactive and hazardous to human health for thousands of years. Proper management and disposal of these materials are crucial to mitigate their environmental impact. Radioactive waste is classified into low-level and high-level waste, with high-level waste, such as spent reactor fuel, posing the greatest long-term risk. Safe storage of this waste requires high-integrity containers and geologically stable sites to prevent leakage and contamination. However, the lack of permanent disposal facilities in many countries has led to temporary storage at nuclear plants, increasing the risk of environmental harm.



Links:
https://nuclear-energy.net/what-is-nuclear-energy/advantages-disadvantages-nuclear-energy/impact-on-the-environment

title: Nuclear power exploitation - Sanction
body:
Nuclear power exploitation indeed carries significant sanction risks due to the dual-use nature of the equipment and raw materials involved. These materials, which are essential for nuclear power generation, can also be used to develop nuclear weapons, making them subject to strict international controls and sanctions. Nuclear power plants themselves are vulnerable to abuse for weapons production and terrorism. The potential for terrorist attacks on nuclear facilities has been a concern since the September 11, 2001, attacks, leading to heightened security measures and regulations by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).



Links:
https://nuclearsuppliersgroup.org/index.php/en/guidelines/nsg-guidelines/guidelines-part-2

title: Nuclear state/weapons - Sanction
body:
A nuclear state is indeed a country that produces nuclear weapons. Countries that have signed and ratified both the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) and the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) generally face lower sanction risks. These treaties aim to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and promote disarmament, thereby reducing the likelihood of sanctions.
The 2022 report "Risky Returns: Nuclear weapon producer and their financiers," jointly published by ICAN (International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons, Nobel Peace Prize winner in 2017) and PAX (a Dutch organization based in Utrecht), provides valuable insights into the financial institutions and their involvement in financing nuclear weapons (Report).

https://disarmament.unoda.org/wmd/nuclear/tpnw/

title: Oil- and/or Gas Industry - AML
body:
As oil and gas companies seek new reserves of natural resources, they often operate in countries with less political stability, infrastructure, and regulatory environments compared to more established markets. These emerging markets are frequently at high risk of conflict, and the significant value attached to oil and gas increases the susceptibility to money laundering and corruption. Tender or contract prices in the oil and gas industry may lack transparency and can be easily manipulated, further exacerbating the risk of money laundering. The Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) encourages countries to publish contracts and license agreements to enhance transparency and reduce corruption.



Links:
https://www.dowjones.com/professional/risk/resources/risk-blog/drilling-into-the-top-compliance-risks-for-oil-gas-extractives-industry-professionals

title: Oil- and/or Gas Industry - Corruption
body:
The oil and gas industry is indeed highly susceptible to corruption and bribery risks, primarily due to its tender-driven nature. Corruption risks and conflicts of interest are prevalent during the process of obtaining contracts and bidding on tenders. In countries where the government may wholly or partially own the sector, oil and gas companies often need to engage with government officials, frequently through well-connected intermediaries. This interaction can lead to corrupt practices, especially when National Oil Companies (NOCs) form joint ventures (JVs) with private companies, and government officials are appointed to the board of directors. Oil and gas companies often hire third parties, such as Engineering, Procurement, and Construction Management (EPCM) firms, to manage their in-country operations. These third-party engagements can further increase the risk of fraud, bribery, and corruption. The complexity of oil and gas projects, which involve multiple components like exploration, drilling, facilities support, transport, and marketing, means that each component introduces another business partner, each posing potential corruption risks.
In the upstream stage, which involves the exploration of oil and gas, obtaining exploration licenses can be a significant source of corruption. Companies may bribe government officials to secure these licenses. In the downstream stage, transport infrastructure such as oil pipelines, ports, and terminals are often characterized as natural monopolies. Corruption and abuse of power can arise when the rules for using these facilities are not transparent or officially published, allowing owners to exercise undue bargaining power.



Links:
https://www.transparency.org/en/our-priorities/extractive-industries

title: Oil- and/or Gas Industry - Environmental
body:
Oil and gas exploration and production operations indeed have the potential for significant environmental impacts. These impacts vary depending on the stage of the process, the size and complexity of the project, the nature and sensitivity of the surrounding environment, and the effectiveness of planning, pollution prevention, mitigation, and control techniques. The extraction (or "winning") of oil and gas can cause substantial environmental and geological damage. This process can disrupt local ecosystems and is associated with inducing earthquakes, particularly in regions where hydraulic fracturing (fracking) is employed. Refining oil and gas also poses environmental risks, primarily through the emission of pollutants that can harm air quality and contribute to climate change. 
The storage and transport of oil and gas products carry the risk of spills, which can have devastating effects on marine and terrestrial environments. Oil spills can lead to long-term ecological damage, affecting wildlife and habitats, and can be challenging and costly to clean up. 'Fracking', in particular, has generated considerable negative media coverage due to its environmental impacts, including groundwater contamination, increased seismic activity, and the release of methane, a potent greenhouse gas. This method of gas extraction remains highly controversial and is likely to continue to be a contentious issue in the future.



Links:
https://www.unepfi.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/Oil-and-Gas-Sector-Risks.pdf

title: Oil- and/or Gas Industry - Fraud
body:
Energy companies that distribute natural gas are indeed exposed to external fraud, particularly through energy theft via fraudulent network connections or unauthorized access. This type of fraud can result in significant financial losses for the companies involved. Managing this risk requires advanced monitoring and detection systems to identify discrepancies in meter readings and unauthorized connections. Internal fraud within the oil and gas industry typically occurs in the invoicing and collection processes. Fraudulent activities in these areas can involve altering usage amounts, manipulating purchasing processes, or changing bank details, all of which can lead to the theft of company revenues. Weak internal controls and poor supervision can provide opportunities for employees to misappropriate assets, further exacerbating the risk of fraud.



Links:
https://crigroup.com/industry/oil-gas-energy/

title: Oil- and/or Gas Industry - Sanction
body:
In recent years, the United States and European Union have indeed intensified the use of sanctions to exert pressure on governments and oil companies globally, aiming to influence their behaviors. These sanctions programs have become increasingly targeted, not only preventing trade with specific countries, government regimes, companies, or individuals but also prohibiting investments in the energy sector and the supply of essential equipment and technologies for oil and gas exploration and production.
This approach particularly impacts countries like Iran, Russia, and Venezuela, which possess significant oil deposits and are key suppliers of crude oil and petrochemical products. For instance, the U.S. Department of the Treasury recently imposed sweeping sanctions on Russia's oil production and exports, targeting major companies like Gazprom Neft and Surgutneftegas, as well as numerous oil-carrying vessels and oilfield service providers. Similarly, the European Union has expanded its sanctions to include additional trade restrictions and asset freezes, further intensifying pressure on Russia's energy sector. Sanctions on Iran and Venezuela have also been stringent. The U.S. has reinstated strict policies to reduce Iran's oil exports to zero, aiming to curb its nuclear program. Venezuela's state-owned oil company, PDVSA, has faced significant restrictions, leading to a dramatic decrease in the country's oil output.



Links:
https://www.skadden.com/insights/publications/2025/03/latest-eu-sanctions-extend-asset-freezes-restrict-oil-industry-dealings-and-target-shadow-fleet

title: Palm Oil - Environmental
body:
The manufacturing of palm oil indeed causes significant environmental issues, including water shortages and deforestation. Palm oil production is a major driver of deforestation, particularly in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, where vast areas of tropical rainforest are cleared to make way for plantations. This deforestation not only contributes to the loss of biodiversity but also exacerbates climate change by releasing stored carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Water shortages are another critical concern. Palm oil plantations require substantial amounts of water, which can lead to the depletion of local water resources, affecting both ecosystems and communities. The palm oil manufacturing process generates various types of waste, including solid waste, liquid waste, and air emissions, which can contaminate soil and waterways.
Human rights abuses on palm oil plantations are also a significant issue. In the Democratic Republic of Congo, for example, workers on oil palm plantations have been exposed to toxic chemicals, paid extremely low wages, and housed in poor conditions. These abusive practices highlight the need for stringent oversight and enforcement of labor rights to protect workers and ensure ethical production standards.



Links:
https://www.nordeaassetmanagement.com/insights/facing-the-esg-risks-of-palm-oil-production/#

title: Paper and Pulp - Corruption
body:
The paper and pulp industry, which involves manufacturing paper from pulp, is indeed vulnerable to corruption and bribery risks. The primary source of fiber for the pulp industry remains forests and tree plantations, making it closely linked to the industrial forestry sector. This sector is often associated with bribery scandals, which ultimately expose the pulp and paper sectors to significant corruption risks.
In some countries, pulp companies are actively involved in the destruction and degradation of natural forests. The forestry sector frequently engages in illegal logging and bribery, further exacerbating these risks. Companies may bribe officials to facilitate illegal logging activities, and corruption in logging is often driven by a lack of institutional capacity to monitor and enforce existing legal and policy frameworks, as well as low transparency and accountability. Moreover, the use of corrupt means to secure illegal licenses and concessions to exploit a country’s forests does not cease once the contract is issued, perpetuating the industry's susceptibility to corruption. For instance, in Indonesia, several government officials were jailed for accepting bribes from timber companies to issue logging licenses, highlighting the pervasive nature of corruption in this sector.



Links:
https://environmentalpaper.org/2012/05/ngos-paper-products-tainted-by-corruption/

title: Paper and Pulp - Environmental
body:
The paper and pulp industry indeed poses significant environmental risks. The manufacturing process involves the use of chemicals for pulping and bleaching, such as chlorine, lead, mercury, and phosphorus, which can lead to pollution and have serious health impacts on workers. Prolonged exposure to these toxic chemicals can cause respiratory illnesses, skin conditions, and other long-term health effects.
The environmental impact of these toxic releases is substantial. These chemicals can contaminate water sources and soil, leading to broader ecological damage. The industry is also a significant contributor to deforestation, particularly in countries where pulp companies are involved in the destruction and degradation of natural forests. This deforestation not only threatens biodiversity but also contributes to climate change by releasing stored carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The pulp and paper industry has been associated with abuses of land rights of local communities and indigenous peoples. In some regions, companies have been implicated in illegal logging and land grabbing, leading to social conflicts and environmental degradation. These practices highlight the need for stringent regulations and enforcement to protect both the environment and the rights of local communities.



Links:
https://wwf.panda.org/discover/our_focus/forests_practice/forestry/pulp_and_paper/

title: Paper and Pulp - Tax
body:
The paper and pulp industry carries significant tax evasion risks. One common method involves declaring the sale of wood products at prices below market value to reduce declared profits and, consequently, corporate and income taxes. This practice, known as transfer mispricing, allows companies to minimize their tax liabilities by manipulating the prices at which goods are sold between related entities.
Another prevalent form of tax evasion in this industry is overvaluing services received from related companies. By inflating the costs of these services, companies can reduce their declared profits and lower their tax obligations. This tactic is often employed through complex transfer pricing arrangements, where services are billed at artificially high prices to shift profits to jurisdictions with lower tax rates. For example, the Indonesian paper giant APRIL has been accused of misreporting its wood pulp exports to reduce its tax bill, shifting large profits overseas and depriving the Indonesian government of substantial tax revenue. Similarly, PT Toba Pulp Lestari (TPL) and APRIL were found to have misclassified their exports to China, resulting in significant tax losses for Indonesia.



Links:
https://www.idpublications.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Full-Paper-CORPORATE-PRACTICE-OF-TRANSFER-PRICING-AND-TAX-EVASION-EMERGING-PROBLEMS-AND-EXISTING-SOLUTIONS.pdf

title: Pawnbrokering - AML
body:
Pawn shops, functioning as Non-Bank Financial Institutions (NBFIs), are considered high-risk for Anti-Money Laundering (AML) purposes. These establishments are cash-intensive businesses, which means they handle large volumes of cash transactions, making them susceptible to money laundering and other illicit activities. The nature of their business, which involves lending money in exchange for valuable items, attracts individuals looking to exploit the system for criminal purposes.
Pawnbrokers are at risk of being offered stolen goods, which can complicate their operations and expose them to legal liabilities. Additionally, the high volume of cash transactions makes it easier for money launderers to integrate illicit funds into the financial system without attracting immediate suspicion. This risk is further compounded by the challenges in verifying the legitimacy of the items being pawned and the identities of the individuals involved.



Links:
https://reidellawfirm.com/aml-compliance-for-pawnbrokers/

title: Pharmaceutical Industry - AML
body:
Pharmaceutical crime indeed involves the manufacture, trade, and distribution of fake, stolen, or illicit medicines and medical devices. This encompasses the counterfeiting and falsification of medical products, their packaging, and associated documentation, as well as theft, fraud, illicit diversion, smuggling, trafficking, and the illegal trade of medical products. The money laundering associated with these activities is a significant concern, as organized criminal networks are attracted by the substantial profits that can be made through pharmaceutical crime. Counterfeit and illicit medicines pose serious risks to public health, as they often contain incorrect or harmful ingredients. The global nature of pharmaceutical crime means that it affects countries worldwide, either as source, transit, or destination points.

https://www.amlrightsource.com/resources/the-case-for-enhanced-due-diligence-in-the-pharma-sector-and-how-to-achieve-it/

title: Pharmaceutical Industry - Corruption
body:
The pharmaceutical industry is one of the most at-risk sectors for bribery and corruption enforcement. The industry is vulnerable to corruption through sponsorships and donations to scientific research. These financial contributions can sometimes be used to influence research outcomes or gain favorable treatment from regulatory bodies. The high level of interaction between the pharmaceutical industry and public health officials further exacerbates these risks, making stringent anti-corruption measures essential to maintain integrity and public trust.
According to the report by Transparency International, the pharmaceutical sector is highly complex, with significant government intervention and often inadequate regulatory systems to properly govern the value chain. This complexity and regulatory inadequacy create numerous opportunities for corrupt practices. Examples of corruption in the pharmaceutical industry include pharmaceutical companies bribing doctors to prescribe their medicines regardless of medical necessity, and government employees facilitating the infiltration of substandard medicines into the distribution system. Corruption can occur in both the public and private sectors, involving a range of actors such as healthcare professionals, government officials, and pharmaceutical company employees.



Links:
https://www.accountancyage.com/2024/03/27/industry-insight-top-fraud-and-bribery-risks-for-pharmaceutical-and-life-sciences/

title: Pharmaceutical Industry - Environmental
body:
Pharmaceutical pollution is increasingly recognized as a significant threat to ecosystems and human health globally. Pharmaceuticals can impact the environment during production, use, and disposal. The environmental impact of pharmaceutical pollution includes the release of toxic substances such as chlorine, lead, mercury, and phosphorus, which can cause serious health risks. These pollutants can contaminate water sources, affecting aquatic ecosystems and human health.
Uncontrolled discharges from pharmaceutical manufacturing have devastating effects on water systems, leading to the spread of resistant bacteria that can harm humans and animals. This issue is particularly severe in countries like India and China, where high-profile pollution scandals at antibiotics production sites have resulted in the spread of drug-resistant bacteria.



Links:
https://eeb.org/the-problem-of-pharmaceutical-pollution/

title: Pharmaceutical Industry - Fraud
body:
Pharmaceutical fraud encompasses various deceptive practices that pose significant risks to public health and safety. One major form of fraud involves the trade of counterfeit drugs, where individuals or companies falsely claim to be authorized manufacturers of another firm's products, often using the firm's mark to deceive the public. These counterfeit drugs can contain incorrect ingredients, incorrect dosages, or even harmful substances, creating serious challenges for healthcare professionals and patients. Pharmaceutical companies may deliberately manufacture and market products that do not contain the required active ingredients or the correct amount of active ingredients. This type of fraud can lead to ineffective treatments and adverse health outcomes for patients who rely on these medications.
Other prevalent issues are the packaging and labeling of drugs with false claims regarding their medical properties, including the active medical ingredients, expiration dates, or storage methods. Also invoice fraud is prevalent in the pharmaceutical industry. These fraudulent practices can mislead consumers and healthcare providers, resulting in the use of substandard or unsafe medications.

https://crigroup.com/pharmaceutical-industry-fraud/

body:
The pharmaceutical industry indeed poses significant sanction risks, particularly when distributing or exporting unlicensed medical-use products to sanctioned countries such as Iran and Sudan. Sanctions imposed by entities like the U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) and the European Union aim to restrict economic activities with these countries due to geopolitical and security concerns.

title: Ports - AML
body:
Ports, particularly free ports, are conducive to secrecy and have preferential treatment that resembles offshore financial centers. They offer high security and discretion, allowing transactions to be made without attracting the attention of regulators or direct tax authorities. This environment makes them attractive for money laundering activities.
The process of declaring the value of goods stored in a port is typically done by the owner or a representative through 'self-declaration.' In many cases, this value is not thoroughly checked, which can facilitate money laundering through goods without detection. Free ports are under critical scrutiny by authorities due to the significant risks of money laundering and tax evasion. Concerns have been raised that free ports could be used to hide illegally acquired assets and launder money.

https://complyadvantage.com/insights/free-ports-aml-risks/

title: Ports - Corruption
body:
Corruption in ports and borders often manifests in collusive forms to evade tariffs and taxes, as well as coercive bribery where port or customs officials extract bribes from companies or individuals for performing routine processes. This type of corruption involves various actors, including customs officials, border guards, and port operators, each with different powers and bureaucratic mandates, resulting in varying discretionary powers and opportunities to extract bribes.
Customs officials, for example, are responsible for collecting taxes on specific types of goods and ensuring that import/export procedures are adhered to. Their role grants them greater discretionary powers and opportunities to extract bribes compared to port operators. The Maritime Anti-Corruption Network (MACN) has documented the impact of corruption in ports, noting that bribes can increase shipping costs by up to 14% for a standard 20ft container. This corruption not only raises the cost of trade but also facilitates illegal activities such as smuggling, tax evasion, and cross-border crimes.

title: Ports - Environmental
body:
During cargo handling operations in ports, discharges and emissions can and do occur, often accidentally. Handling dry bulk cargo such as grain, coal, iron ore, and china clay can produce dust, while handling liquid bulks through pipelines poses risks of leaks, emissions, and spillages. These activities can lead to atmospheric pollution from cargo vapor emissions. The release of cargoes into the marine environment can have direct environmental effects, such as the loss of toxic substances, or indirect effects, like the loss of non-toxic organic-rich substances, which may result in oxygen depletion as they break down. For example, the accidental release of fertilizers or animal feed with high biological oxygen demands can cause local oxygen depletion, suffocating marine life. Noise pollution from cargo handling operations is another significant concern. The noise generated can disturb animals and birds inhabiting marine environments. This disturbance can affect their natural behaviors and habitats, leading to broader ecological impacts.

title: Ports - Tax
body:
Ports, especially free ports, indeed carry significant tax evasion risks. Goods stored in free ports or under customs warehousing procedures are technically considered 'in transit,' even though there are often no time limits on how long they can remain there. This system allows goods to gain value and be traded multiple times without being taxed, facilitating tax-free sales. Goods entering free ports are not subject to customs duties or value-added tax (VAT), which makes these areas attractive for tax evasion. The lack of stringent oversight and the ability to self-declare the value of goods without thorough checks further exacerbate these risks. Critics argue that free ports can be used to hide illegally acquired assets and launder money, as they offer high security and discretion similar to offshore financial centers.

title: Prepaid/Saved Value Cards Business - AML
body:
Prepaid cards and gift cards indeed pose significant Anti-Money Laundering (AML) risks. These cards can be easily purchased with illicit cash, allowing criminals to integrate illegal funds into the economy through retail purchases. The anonymity and ease of use associated with prepaid cards make them attractive tools for money laundering and terrorist financing. Organized criminals and terrorists exploit prepaid cards in various ways to launder illicit proceeds and transfer money anonymously across the globe. For instance, they can purchase large quantities of prepaid cards with illegal funds and then use these cards to buy high-value goods, which can be resold for clean money. Prepaid cards can be used to transfer funds internationally without attracting the attention of financial regulators.
Several features make these cards particularly vulnerable to misuse: the ease and speed of transferring funds, the ability to move unactivated cards across borders, limited audit trails, and difficulty in tracking multiple transactions. Some programs also lack proper identity verification or personal contact, and their broad acceptance makes them highly negotiable, further increasing the risk of money laundering.

title: Public Adminstration Services - AML
body:
Public administration services can indeed be exploited for money laundering activities. The illegal movement of cash, misinvoicing of goods, and the use of bearer negotiable instruments across borders are common methods used by money launderers. The porous nature of borders in many regions exacerbates this issue, making it easier for illicit funds to be moved undetected.
For instance, the U.S. Department of the Treasury has highlighted the risks associated with cross-border money laundering, particularly in regions with less stringent border controls. The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) has issued Geographic Targeting Orders (GTOs) to combat illicit activities and money laundering along the southwest border of the United States, underscoring the significant risk posed by border porosity. Moreover, the International Journal of Research Publication and Reviews has discussed how porous borders in countries like Nigeria facilitate various forms of transnational crime, including money laundering.

title: Public Adminstration Services - Corruption
body:
The lack of accountability and transparency in public administration services indeed fosters corruption. Corrupt officials often make biased decisions that benefit their private interests at the expense of the public, misusing taxpayers' money. Resources intended for productive uses are diverted to corrupt practices, undermining public trust and efficiency.
Low salaries of public administration employees significantly contribute to corruption. Underpaid officials may seek to supplement their income by accepting bribes in exchange for providing certain administrative services. This issue is particularly pronounced in regions where public sector wages are insufficient and irregularly paid. Public administration services, especially at borders, are highly susceptible to corruption due to their porous nature. The ease with which people can cross borders facilitates various illegal activities, including human and drug trafficking, weapon smuggling, organized crime, and terrorism. Corrupt arrangements often develop between border officials and individuals crossing the border, further exacerbating these issues.

title: Public Adminstration Services - Environmental
body:
Public administration locations, particularly border controls, indeed face significant environmental risks due to high levels of littering. Border trash has been shown to adversely affect human health, the environment, and economic wellbeing. Specific environmental impacts at border posts include watershed degradation, soil erosion, damage to infrastructure, loss of vegetation and wildlife. Moreover, escaped campfires caused by migrants have resulted in wildfires, further damaging the environment and infrastructure. These fires not only destroy vegetation but also threaten endangered species and their habitats. The economic costs associated with cleaning up border trash and repairing damaged infrastructure are substantial, placing a financial burden on local communities.
For instance, the accumulation of trash along the U.S.-Mexico border has led to severe environmental degradation. Between 2007 and 2018, border agents collected 460,000 pounds of trash discarded by illegal migrants along the Arizona-Mexico border. This trash includes human waste, backpacks, medical products, plastic, vehicles, and clothing, all of which pose risks to wildlife and their habitats. The presence of trash can lead to soil erosion and watershed degradation, impacting the quality of water sources and the stability of the soil.

title: Public Adminstration Services - Fraud
body:
Frauds within the public sector, including State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), indeed originate from both internal and external sources. Internal frauds can be committed by employees at any level within the organization, ranging from small-scale abuses of travel expenses to large-scale frauds involving high-value contracts and breaches of controls that could have serious and material consequences.
For example, procurement fraud, payroll fraud, and fraudulent expenditure claims are common types of internal fraud in the public sector. These can include false invoicing, misuse of credit cards, and manipulation of the procurement process to benefit certain parties. Additionally, accounting fraud, such as accounting or reporting manipulations, has become a significant concern in recent years. This type of fraud involves altering financial statements to present a misleading picture of an organization's financial health, which can have severe repercussions for public trust and financial stability. External frauds, on the other hand, often involve collusion between public officials and external parties, such as vendors or contractors, to defraud the government. These frauds can include bribery, corruption, and kickbacks, where public officials receive illicit payments in exchange for favorable treatment or contracts.

title: Real Estate & Construction Industry - AML
body:
The real estate industry is a high-risk segment for money laundering. The market has long been a favored avenue for individuals to launder or invest stolen money and other illicitly gained funds. The high value of real estate makes it particularly attractive for money laundering activities. Real estate transactions often involve large sums of money, which can be used to conceal the origins of illicit funds. The fluctuating prices in the real estate market further facilitate money laundering, as criminals can exploit these variations to move money undetected. The lack of transparency in real estate pricing and the use of complex ownership structures, such as shell companies and trusts, make it difficult to trace the true beneficial owners.
In high-risk countries, cash transactions in real estate are more common, increasing the risk of money laundering. Cash payments allow criminals to bypass traditional financial systems and avoid scrutiny. For example, the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) estimated that in 2020, over $1 billion was laundered through Australian real estate by Chinese interests alone.

title: Real Estate & Construction Industry - Corruption
body:
The real estate industry is indeed prone to high corruption risks. When purchasing from the state, there is a significant risk of corruption and conflicts of interest during the bidding process for tenders. This vulnerability is exacerbated in large projects, where the stakes are higher, and the potential for bribing decision-makers involved in selling or buying real estate increases. Corruption in the real estate sector often involves offering bribes to government officials or other influential parties to secure favorable outcomes, such as obtaining permits, winning contracts, or influencing property valuations. This not only undermines fair competition but also leads to inflated project costs and substandard work, ultimately harming the public interest.
Furthermore, nitrous oxide and ammonia emissions released during the construction of new houses have led to stringent nitrogen emission quotas, making it increasingly difficult to obtain permissions for new housing projects. This situation has made the industry more vulnerable to corruption, with increased attempts to bribe government officials to secure building permissions. The complexity and urgency of obtaining these permissions can lead to corrupt practices, where officials may be offered inducements to expedite or approve projects that would otherwise face regulatory hurdles. For instance, in the Netherlands, the nitrogen crisis has prevented the construction of thousands of homes, highlighting the impact of environmental regulations on housing development.

title: Real Estate & Construction Industry - Environmental
body:
The real estate and construction industry faces a wide range of pollution liability exposures, both directly and indirectly. Environmental hazards in this sector can cause death, serious bodily injury, property damage, or diminution in value (DIV), leading to costly liability claims.
Common environmental risks include contamination from hazardous materials such as asbestos and lead-based paint. Pollution from construction activities, such as the release of nitrous oxide and ammonia, can have significant environmental impacts. These pollutants can degrade air and water quality, harm local ecosystems, and pose health risks to nearby communities. Real estate companies are also frequently held liable for historical contamination they did not create or knew little about. This can include legacy pollution from previous industrial activities on a site, which can be costly to remediate and may affect property values. Furthermore, the presence of underground storage tanks, improper disposal of construction waste, and the use of hazardous chemicals during construction can all contribute to environmental liabilities.

title: Real Estate & Construction Industry - Fraud
body:
A fraud-susceptible environment in the real estate and construction industry is indeed fostered by several factors, including weak or lack of internal controls, use of related parties, joint venture parties in unfamiliar jurisdictions, poorly designed project scopes, poorly worded contracts, employee/supplier collusion, use of undocumented workers, and cash transactions. Common fraud schemes in the real estate and construction industry include bid rigging, billing schemes, cheque tampering, expense account abuse, stealing non-cash assets, material switching, falsifying payments, use of phantom suppliers, and payroll schemes. 
Bid rigging involves collusion between contractors to manipulate the bidding process, ensuring that a particular contractor wins the contract at an inflated price. Billing schemes can include overcharging for materials or labor, or billing for work that was never performed. Employee and supplier collusion is another significant risk, where insiders collaborate with external parties to defraud the company. This can involve falsifying invoices, diverting materials, or manipulating project costs. The use of undocumented workers and cash transactions further complicates the detection and prevention of fraud, as these practices can bypass traditional financial controls and oversight.

title: Recruitment and Employment Agencies - AML
body:
Due to the increased online presence, money launderers have found ways to circulate their illegally obtained money through online job scams. Fraudulent employers often post online job listings offering lucrative work-from-home opportunities, preying on job seekers looking for simple remote jobs. These scams can involve money laundering, where criminals recruit unsuspecting individuals to help move illicit funds through legitimate accounts.
Shell companies are frequently set up by individuals who counterfeit checks or cash and need to circulate it through legitimate accounts. These transactions are typically small enough to avoid detection by financial institutions. The anonymity and complexity of online job scams make it difficult for authorities to trace the origins of the illicit funds. For example, the FBI has warned that job postings promising easy money for little effort could be illegal schemes recruiting money mules. Criminals use these schemes to launder money obtained through scams, human trafficking, and drug trafficking. Job seekers are often asked to open bank accounts, receive funds, and then transfer them, unknowingly participating in money laundering activities.

title: Recruitment and Employment Agencies - Corruption
body:
Recruitment and employment practices are indeed particularly vulnerable to corruption risks. Kickbacks can occur when an external recruiting agent and an internal recruiting manager agree on unauthorized incentives given to the recruiting manager in exchange for preferential treatment for the recruiting vendor who represents candidates submitted for hire. This practice undermines the integrity of the recruitment process and can lead to the hiring of less qualified candidates based on favoritism rather than merit.
Corruption risks associated with the use of recruitment agencies can range from the circumvention of merit-based selection and probity processes to complex schemes like 'double dipping.' Double dipping occurs when an employee at a public sector agency establishes a company to use recruitment agencies to hire associates at inflated fees. This scheme allows the employee to benefit financially from both their public sector position and their private company, creating significant conflicts of interest and financial misconduct.

title: Recruitment and Employment Agencies - Fraud
body:

External fraud can occur when outsiders pose as company officials and accept deposits from candidates for fictitious jobs. This type of scam preys on job seekers, exploiting their desire for employment and often resulting in financial loss and emotional distress for the victims.
Internally, recruitment agencies may face the risk of ghost employees. This occurs when employees make payments to individuals who are listed on the payroll but do not actually exist or work for the company. Ghost employees are fictitious entities created by dishonest employees to illicitly draw earnings. This type of fraud can significantly impact an organization's financial health, as it involves the misallocation of resources and undermines the integrity of payroll systems.

title: Rental and Leasing Services - Fraud
body:
Fraud is indeed widespread in the rental and leasing services sector, often going unnoticed by property managers. Many unemployed or underemployed individuals commit rental application fraud to secure apartments they wouldn’t otherwise qualify for. To reduce fraud risk, it's crucial to understand the main types: first-party, third-party, and synthetic identity fraud.
First-party fraud involves applicants using their real identity but providing false information, such as altered pay stubs, to appear more financially stable than they are. These fraudsters may secure housing they can’t afford or never intend to pay for.
Third-party fraud occurs when someone uses another person's identity—without their knowledge—to apply for a rental. They may use stolen personal data like names or Social Security numbers to pass tenant screenings.
Synthetic identity fraud combines real and fake information to create a new, fictional identity. This advanced form of fraud is growing rapidly, with fraudsters using these made-up personas to apply for rentals, making detection more difficult.

title: Retail Industry - AML
body:
The retail industry, especially fast food chains, is indeed vulnerable to money laundering due to its cash-intensive nature. Criminals can exploit these businesses by adding illicit cash to the legitimate revenues, making it appear as though the money came from customers. This method allows the management or owners of the company to launder larger amounts of money, integrating criminal proceeds into the legitimate financial system.
Money laundering in the food industry can take several forms, including over/under-invoicing, cash transactions, and the use of shell companies and fake suppliers. These methods help disguise the origins of illicit funds and make them appear as legitimate business activities. The extensive global supply chains and complex international trade networks in the food sector further facilitate money laundering operations.

title: Retail Industry - Corruption
body:
The retail sector, like other worldwide sourcing industries, is indeed prone to various forms of corruption. Large retail chains operating in developing countries often face corrupt bureaucracy and struggle with dubious administrative processes. This environment can lead to situations where manufacturers are tempted to pay bribes to secure million-dollar deals with the purchasing divisions of large retailers. One of the most controversial concerns in the retail industry is the practice of slotting fees. Slotting fees are charged to manufacturers as a contribution to the handling costs of the retailer. These fees are negotiated in secrecy and are not broken down by categories of expenditure, making them often seen as bribery-like payments demanded for getting contracts or staying in business. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has studied slotting allowances in the retail grocery industry, highlighting the opaque nature of these fees and their potential to foster corrupt practices.

title: Robotics - Environmental
body:
The environmental risks associated with robotics are significant, particularly due to the unequal distribution of robotic technology. A handful of countries, such as China, the US, South Korea, and Japan, use more than half of the global stock of robots. This concentration of automation in rich and advanced countries leaves poorer nations struggling to catch up, exacerbating global inequality. This inequality contributes to environmental damage in several ways. Rich countries benefit from increased efficiency and productivity through automation, while poorer countries face the worst impacts of climate change-indicative catastrophes. The surge in robotics usage by the wealthiest nations drives resource depletion and environmental degradation, as these countries consume more resources and produce more waste.
The environmental impact of robotics includes excessive energy consumption and accelerated resource depletion. Industrial robots require significant amounts of energy to operate, leading to higher emissions, especially if the power is sourced from fossil fuels. The rapid production enabled by robotics also boosts consumption, leading to planned obsolescence and increased waste.

title: Second hand automotive and parts dealership - Environment
sector: Second hand automotive and parts dealership
body:
Owners of second-hand automotive dealerships are indeed held liable for environmental risks associated with their operations. This includes spills and releases of spent solvents, used oil, gasoline, or other pollutants into soil, surface water, groundwater, and air. When the owner is in control of the property, they are responsible for ensuring compliance with environmental regulations to prevent contamination.
The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) imposes strict liability on property owners for contamination, including the costs of remediation. This means that even if the contamination occurred before the current owner took control, they could still be held responsible for cleanup costs.

title: Second hand automotive and parts dealership - Fraud
sector: Second hand automotive and parts dealership
body:
Internal fraud in second-hand car dealerships is indeed common, particularly through the practice known as "clocking." Clocking refers to the artificial modification of a car's mileage to increase its value when selling. By reducing the recorded mileage, sellers can make the car appear less used and more valuable, which is a clear incentive for fraudulent activity. Criminals often engage in clocking when the car's mileage has exceeded a certain threshold.
Clocking can significantly impact the safety and reliability of the vehicle, as higher mileage cars are more prone to wear and tear. Unsuspecting buyers may end up paying more for a vehicle that has hidden mechanical issues due to its actual mileage. This practice not only defrauds consumers but also poses serious safety risks.



Links:
https://www.justia.com/consumer/deceptive-practices-and-fraud/auto-dealer-fraud/

title: Telecommunications Industry - Corruption
body:
The telecommunications industry is indeed highly susceptible to corruption and bribery, particularly during the licensing process. This vulnerability stems from the industry's strategic importance, high revenue generation potential, and complex technical and governance structures. The deep interrelations between public and private sector components further exacerbate the risk of undue influence and corrupt practices.
The licensing process is especially prone to corruption due to its complexity and the significant financial stakes involved. Corruption in this sector can manifest in various forms, including bribery of officials to secure licenses, manipulation of regulatory frameworks, and the creation of slush funds to influence decision-makers.

https://www.hoganlovells.com/en/publications/corruption-in-the-telecoms-sector-beware-the-elephant-in-the-room

title: Telecommunications Industry - Environmental
body:
The telecommunications industry is indeed heavily reliant on power, from major power plants and cooling systems used by large data centers to the embedded power suppliers required by servers. With rising energy prices, there is a strong financial impetus for telecom companies to reduce their total power usage. This has led the industry to prioritize environmental issues and respond to customer demands for sustainable development.
Telecom operators are increasingly adopting energy optimization measures to lower costs and meet decarbonization goals. For instance, companies can achieve significant savings by combining technology solutions with site and equipment optimization, pricing, and operational levers.

https://inform.tmforum.org/features-and-opinion/our-power-our-planet-renewable-energy-in-the-telco-industry

title: Telecommunications Industry - Fraud
body: Fraud attacks in the telecommunications industry are increasingly targeting customers rather than directly impacting the telecom companies' bottom line. With the growth of smartphone technology, there has been a rise in targeted fraud attacks aimed at obtaining high-value handsets for resale. These handsets are often acquired through subscription, application, identity, and account takeover fraud, where genuine identities are stolen or used to open accounts, or existing accounts are manipulated to add extra services without permission. Fraudsters exploit the competitive marketplace, self-service, and online portals, or limited security for existing accounts to obtain equipment that can be resold internationally for high value.

title: Telecommunications Industry - nan
body:
The telecommunications industry faces significant operational risks, specifically espionage/cybersecurity. Foreign intelligence services attempt to obtain relevant information through individuals with direct or indirect access or by deploying technical devices and mobile hardware. For example, concerns have been raised about Chinese companies like Huawei and ZTE potentially facilitating espionage through their telecommunications equipment. This has led to growing concerns about the security of telecommunications networks worldwide, with fears that government authorities could use communications technologies to facilitate cyber-attacks or espionage. The exploitation of telecommunications by foreign governments presents a potentially grave national security risk.

title: Textiles (Trade/Manufacturing/Wholesale) - AML
body:
Criminals often exploit the trade of textiles by misrepresenting the quality or quantity of goods as they move across borders and through various suppliers. This misrepresentation can involve over- and under-invoicing, multiple invoicing, over- and under-shipment, and false descriptions of goods, all of which provide a legal cover for the movement of illicit funds.
Over-invoicing and under-invoicing are common techniques used in TBML. Over-invoicing involves inflating the value of goods on invoices to transfer larger sums of money, while under-invoicing involves declaring a lower value to evade taxes and duties. Multiple invoicing refers to issuing several invoices for the same shipment to justify multiple payments. False descriptions of goods can also be used to disguise the true nature of transactions, making it difficult for authorities to detect illegal activities.



Links:
https://www.globaltrademag.com/from-fashion-textiles-to-money-laundering/

title: Textiles (Trade/Manufacturing/Wholesale) - Corruption
body:
Corruption is pervasive in the textiles industry. Bribery is common in the process of obtaining licenses and permits, as well as during safety inspections. Factory owners often resort to bribing officials to bypass safety checks, even when significant dangers are identified within the company. This practice not only compromises worker safety but also undermines regulatory efforts to ensure safe working conditions.
The textiles industry faces numerous integrity risks, including bribery and kickbacks, which are prevalent in global supply chains. For example, requests for payments for favorable findings by auditors or merchandisers demanding commissions from suppliers are common. Bribery of foreign officials is a significant issue, particularly in securing licenses to operate.

https://www.whitecase.com/insight-our-thinking/high-value-high-risk-bribery-corruption-and-fraud-threats-luxury-goods-sector

title: Textiles (Trade/Manufacturing/Wholesale) - Environment
body:
The textiles industry indeed faces significant environmental risks, particularly in factories located in low-wage countries. These factories have experienced numerous accidents, contributing to the industry's high reputational risk. The sector is fraught with hazards, including exposure to noise, dangerous substances, manual handling, and dangerous machinery. Each stage of textile processing—from material production to manufacturing, finishing, coloring, and packaging—poses risks to workers, with some being particularly dangerous for women's health.
Air pollution is another critical issue in the textiles industry. The processing of cotton generates cotton dust, which includes a mix of cotton fibers, chemical pesticides, and soil. This dust can become airborne and, if workers are not properly masked, can lead to serious lung issues. Moreover, the industry is notorious for bribery cases involving the acquisition of licenses and permits, as well as safety inspections, even when significant dangers are identified within the company.nThe textiles industry is the second-largest user of water globally. The textile industry is a global enterprise with a massive carbon footprint. It is responsible for 5-10 percent of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

title: Textiles (Trade/Manufacturing/Wholesale) - Operational
body:
The textiles industry indeed faces significant operational risks, particularly related to manual operations. Employees often handle heavy or awkward loads, which can lead to physical strain and injuries. Difficulty in gripping, excessive use of force, repetitive motions, and twisting or other awkward postures are common activities that pose risks to workers' physical well-being. These manual operation risks can result in musculoskeletal disorders, which are prevalent among textile workers due to the nature of their tasks. Ensuring proper ergonomic practices and providing adequate training can help mitigate these risks. Implementing safety measures such as using mechanical aids for lifting and handling, and promoting regular breaks to reduce repetitive strain, are crucial steps in protecting workers.

title: Tobacco Farming - Corruption
body:
The tobacco industry's strong desire to increase tobacco use indeed opens the door for potential government bribery and corruption to prevent the implementation of tobacco control laws and policies. Tobacco farmers often resort to bribing government officials to obtain licenses for farming their products. This practice undermines regulatory efforts and public health initiatives aimed at controlling tobacco use.
Tobacco farmers can falsify their production records to insurance companies to claim damages for their crops and receive insurance payments to which they are not entitled. This type of fraud is not uncommon and has been documented in various cases. Additionally, tobacco farmers may make cash payments to officials of the tobacco authority to obtain export licenses and gain access to government-owned tobacco-processing facilities.

https://oneill.law.georgetown.edu/tobacco-industry-bribery-and-anticorruption/

title: Tobacco Farming - Environmental
body:
The harmful impact of the tobacco industry on the environment is indeed vast and growing. Tobacco farming contributes significantly to deforestation, climate change, and pollution. The cultivation of tobacco plants requires large quantities of chemicals, including insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, and fumigants, as well as growth regulators like growth inhibitors and ripening agents. These chemicals are essential for controlling pest and disease outbreaks but are often so harmful to both the environment and farmers' health that they are banned in some countries.
In low- and middle-income countries, these pesticides and growth inhibitors are typically applied using handheld or backpack sprayers, often without the necessary protective equipment. This practice increases the likelihood of skin and respiratory exposure to toxic chemicals, posing serious health risks to farmers. The environmental impact of tobacco farming extends beyond chemical use. The industry is a major contributor to deforestation, as large areas of forest are cleared to make way for tobacco cultivation. This deforestation leads to soil degradation, loss of biodiversity, and disruption of ecosystems.

title: Trade in high value products - AML Risk - AML
sector: Trade in high value products - AML Risk
body:
Trade in high-value products such as exclusive vehicles, yachts, antiques, and art is indeed a cash-intensive sector, making it highly susceptible to money laundering. Criminals often purchase these high-value items with cash obtained from non-ethical activities, effectively laundering their illicit funds.
Art, in particular, is an attractive vehicle for money laundering due to its ability to be hidden or smuggled. Transactions in the art market are often private, with prices being subjective and easily manipulated. Fine arts and antiques are notoriously difficult to price, making it challenging for reviewers to determine if purchasers are overpaying, which could indicate a potentially illicit transaction. Moreover, over half of the art market is facilitated by private dealers, where prices remain private and sellers are not legally obligated to disclose the price paid or their financial interests in the piece.

title: Trade in high value products - AML Risk - Corruption
sector: Trade in high value products - AML Risk
body:
High-value products can indeed facilitate bribery of public officials. For instance, an individual can bribe an official to place a high-value product for auction at an inflated price. The individual then purchases the item, offering the official a tidy profit. This method allows the briber to use the high-value product as a form of currency, effectively laundering money while providing a significant financial benefit to the official. The subjective nature of art pricing makes it particularly susceptible to manipulation, allowing officials to inflate or deflate prices to facilitate bribery. 
In China, this practice is so widespread that it has its own name, "elegant bribery" . Elegant bribery involves using cultural products and artifacts, such as antiques, rare plants, paintings, and calligraphy, as mediums for corruption.

title: Trade in high value products - AML Risk - Operational
sector: Trade in high value products - AML Risk
body:
The trade in high-value products, such as exclusive vehicles, yachts, antiques, and art, is particularly susceptible to fraud. Fraud in high-value transactions can take many forms, including payment fraud, asset misrepresentation, non-delivery of goods or services, and cyber threats.
Payment fraud involves misappropriating funds or transferring them to unauthorized accounts. Asset misrepresentation occurs when sellers provide false information about the asset, such as inflating its value or fake mileage scams, which is the most common way of internal fraud in the trade of high value exclusive vehicles. Non-delivery of goods or services is another common issue, where buyers release funds but never receive what they paid for. Cyber threats, including hacking and phishing attacks, can compromise sensitive financial information.

title: Trading Precious Metals - AML
body:
Precious minerals are indeed attractive for trade-based money laundering (TBML) schemes. Precious metals, especially gold, provide a mechanism for organized crime groups to convert illicit cash into a stable, anonymous, transformable, and easily exchangeable asset, allowing them to realize or reinvest the profits of their criminal activities. People and entities can pay a price for scrap gold that is higher than the market price for pure gold, thus laundering their money.
Several characteristics make precious minerals appealing to both legitimate buyers and illicit actors. Precious minerals have a high value, with diamonds being particularly valuable relative to their weight and maintaining a relatively stable price. They are compact and easy to smuggle; gold, for instance, can be melted and cast into any shape. The trade in precious minerals is often conducted in cash, making transactions difficult to trace. These minerals are negotiable worldwide and can be used as a form of currency. They are durable, virtually untraceable, odorless, and difficult to detect when smuggled. Additionally, they can be held anonymously without the need for records, making them a safe investment for those looking to launder money.

title: Transportation - AML
body:
International transportation faces increased risks of criminal activities such as smuggling of illegal goods, arms, drugs, cash, and human trafficking. Transport companies can be exploited to launder the proceeds of these illicit activities.
Cash remains a significant raw material for criminal groups, used as an anonymous financial instrument even in complex money laundering systems. Physical transportation of cash, including bulk cash smuggling (BCS) and cash couriers, continues to be a prevalent method of money laundering worldwide. Criminal organizations smuggle cash across borders to break the audit trail, further obscuring the source of illegally obtained funds. Cash smuggling is used to launder proceeds from various illicit activities, including tax fraud, arms and drug trafficking, and terrorism financing. Cash is often concealed in cargo and adapted freight to evade detection.
