Transport infrastructure provision, from roads to waterways, involves substantial public funds and highly complex projects. This makes it a prime target for corrupt elites across Europe, particularly in countries with high corruption risks. The complexity and scale of these projects create opportunities for corruption, including bribery and embezzlement, which can significantly inflate costs and distort spending structures.

title: Transportation - Fraud
body:
Fraud is indeed a continual threat to the transportation industry, impacting shippers, carriers, brokers, and ultimately increasing the price of goods for consumers. One of the most prevalent fraud-related issues is identity theft, which continues to violate countless drivers throughout the industry. Delinquents often pose as legitimate entities to seize sensitive information, such as payment details.
Another common practice is the loading scam, where fraudsters target brokerages with freight posted on load boards. Scammers typically impersonate legitimate carriers and request a fuel advance, claiming it is needed for over-the-road expenses. Once the fuel advance is issued, the scammers sever all further communications, leaving brokerages without a carrier and facing financial losses.

title: Travel and Accomodation Agencies - AML
body:
Travel and accommodation agencies indeed function as brokers, bringing buyers and sellers together, and are exposed to several money laundering risks. These agencies are knowledgeable about tourist products, including destinations, modes of travel, climate, accommodation, and other service sector areas. They act on behalf of product and service providers in return for a commission.
Criminals often exploit travel agencies to launder money by depositing illegal cash into financial institutions and then transferring the cash overseas by wire if necessary. The ability to launder the proceeds of crime through the banking system is vital to the success of criminal operations. The increased integration of the world’s financial system and the removal of barriers to the free movement of capital have significantly increased money laundering through the banking system. Travel agencies, with their extensive network of transactions and international connections, can facilitate these money laundering practices.

https://www.sanctions.io/blog/ensuring-aml-compliance-in-the-travel-industry

title: Travel and Accomodation Agencies - Fraud
body:
The travel industry is indeed susceptible to fraud risks in several areas, including corporate fraud, travel and entertainment fraud, and violations of company policy. Fraudsters targeting the travel industry are becoming increasingly ingenious, utilizing digital technology to carry out their schemes. Some of the popular new fraud methods include the creation of fake hotel websites, inflated room prices, and the sale of dodgy tickets. These methods exploit the digital nature of travel services, making travel agencies particularly prone to external fraud risks.
Internal corporate fraud can also occur when a company disguises illegitimate payments as travel costs. In such cases, a travel agent might issue a fapiao (a tax invoice controlled by the local tax authority) to the company to satisfy its internal controls. Additionally, a travel agent could receive funds directly and hold them for future use on behalf of the company, effectively creating a slush fund.

title: Trusts - AML
body:
Trusts are legal arrangements developed by common law jurisdictions where the legal title and control of an asset are separated from the equitable interests in that asset. In a trust, assets are legally owned by the "trustees," and the trust itself cannot conduct transactions or hold property in its own right but must do so through the trustees. Trusts are often used as the last layer of secrecy in complex corporate structures, potentially designed to disguise a criminal’s connection to illicit funds.
To aid in this concealment, arrangements often span multiple jurisdictions, with trust assets, Trust and Company Service Providers (TCSPs), and investment management companies each located in different countries. The separation of legal and beneficial ownership makes trusts invaluable for those seeking to distance and disguise their connection with property used for, or generated by, crime. Furthermore, in many jurisdictions, there is no registration requirement for a trust, as they are viewed as private arrangements and their existence is not a matter of public record. This makes trusts well-suited to be used as secrecy vehicles by those wishing to launder money.

https://anti-money-laundering.eu/trusts/

title: Vastgoed - Corruptie
body:
De bouw en ontwikkeling van vastgoed heeft inderdaad een hoog corruptierisico, vooral bij overheidsaanbestedingen of grote opdrachtgevers. Er is een verhoogd risico van omkoping van beslissingsbevoegden om lucratieve contracten te verkrijgen. Rond 2000 speelde in Nederland een groot corruptieschandaal, bekend als de Bouwfraude-affaire. Dit schandaal onthulde grootschalige fraude en prijsafspraken tussen bouwbedrijven, waarbij ambtenaren werden omgekocht om opdrachten te verkrijgen.
Een nieuw risico is de stikstofcrisis. Om stikstofverbindingen zoals ammoniak en stikstofoxiden, die schadelijk zijn voor mens en milieu, terug te dringen, zijn in Nederland 40% van de vergunningen voor bouwprojecten ingetrokken. Dit heeft geleid tot een verhoogd risico dat bedrijven proberen door omkoping toch een vergunning te bemachtigen. De stikstofcrisis heeft een aanzienlijke impact op de bouwsector, waarbij veel projecten vertraging oplopen of zelfs worden stopgezet.

title: Waste Disposal - AML
body:
The waste disposal industry is indeed prone to money laundering risks. A significant amount of waste is illegally dumped in high-risk countries where regulations are less strict. In the EU, the trade in illegal waste is often carried out by larger criminal organizations operating worldwide through legal entities. Cash payments are common in the waste sector, which increases the risk of money laundering.
Profits from illegal waste are considered money laundering because they originate from criminal activities. The key driver for illegal waste shipments to destination countries is the profit generated from payments for safe disposal of waste that is actually dumped or unsafely recycled. In the EU, the trafficking of illicit waste is typically carried out by major organized crime groups with the assistance of legal business structures, corruption, and money laundering activities. In waste disposal, it is still common to perform transactions in cash, which presents a sensitivity to money laundering. Additionally, as the price is based on weight, sale prices are non-transparent and susceptible to accounting fraud. Waste disposal operations may falsify paperwork and tamper with waste scales, sometimes to skim profits from the business and sometimes to hide dirty money.

title: Waste Disposal - Environmental
body:

The management of waste involves a complex set of potential impacts on human health, safety, and the environment. Improper waste disposal can directly threaten workers and requires specialized handling to prevent further harm to the environment and public health.
For instance, the improper disposal of solid waste can lead to the direct spread of infectious diseases. Poorly managed waste sites become breeding grounds for vectors like rats, flies, and mosquitoes, which can spread diseases such as dengue, malaria, and leptospirosis. Additionally, fermentation of waste can attract various disease-spreading factors, exacerbating health risks. Moreover, illegal dumping of hazardous waste can lead to soil contamination, water pollution, and air quality degradation.
